reviewText:
Educational & Relaxing // Perfect For Those Looking To Learn
+ Skill upgrades and store discounts are available via in-game surplus, allowing one to improve their performance when working on repairs
+ Wear and tear is visibly rendered
+ Occasional, subtle humor found throughout many of the repair orders
+ Educational and engaging; excellent tool in self-teaching the basics of automotive function and repair
+ Limited, but enjoyable soundtrack
+ Adds depth by use of a feature which allows one to inspect parts for damage or decay; parts inspected are then color-coded for convenience (this feature can be toggled, thankfully)
+ Test drives do much to help one determine what is not performing optimally; game uses nuances of sound and handling in a very polished fashion
+ Includes 2 free DLC packs and an 'unlimited' repair mode; in particular, the 'unlimited' repair mode helps to increase the chances that one will occasionally return for casual bouts of auto repair (highly likely, as the atmosphere of this title is very relaxed)
+ Sound bytes and crisp visuals make for an immensely satisfying experience
+ Diagnostics tests and chip tuning further add to a feeling of immersion; this becomes more pronounced as your garage is 'upgraded' throughout the central 'campaign' (for lack of a more convenient term)
+ Customer description of problems helps one to correlate malfunctioning componenets with their likely presentable symptoms

- Poor optimization; game runs in a way that is inordinately taxing
- Parts shop has no search feature
- Camera can become frustrating in certain circumstances (namely when working with exhaust systems)
- Not enough variance in cars or basic design; problems, therefore, become predictable a bit early on

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Video First Look Gameplay: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lYnJF_35Yx4

I'm going to say that I recommend this but I think it's worth pointing out some things first, as it's definitely not for everyone but I think there are some people that will like it so I'll explain why.

Basically the aim of the game is to order in parts from the computer, then go and find where those parts are on the car and to take them off and replace them, then run some checks. There isn't that much more to it.

The major part of this game that is worth pointing out is that apart from the very first level, you're left completely on your own. If you don't know where something is or how it works you may find yourself stuck. I spent a great deal of time trying to find where the fuel filter was despite me knowing where one belongs on my own car in real life. However because of this fact, I do feel that makes the simulation part of this game rather accurate. I am not a mechanic and obviously I don't know how to work on a car all that much, and you do kind of feel that way when you play this game. Is that really a sign of a good simulator game though? Should the simulation of menial tasks in a video game make the game almost as boring as real life? I think the prospect of at least tinkering and having a go in the comfort of your house without getting dirty is what may warm some people towards this game. Perhaps namely, the teenage car enthusiast / wannabe mechanic market.

reviewText:
It's not a tremendously accurate simulation by any means, but it's great fun nonetheless, and it might even teach you some of the basics about how cars are put together.  The repairs themselves usually follow a standard plot:  run diagnostics (test drive, OBD checker, etc) or examine the parts yourself until you find the one or two parts that are bad, remove as many parts as are necessary to remove the bad parts, buy replacements for the bad parts from your garage computer (or repair them if possible), then install the new parts and replace everything else.

At least, that's how it's *supposed* to go.  If you want to go a different (*cough* chop shop *cough*) route, you can make use of the otherwise mostly useless used parts store also on your garage's computer.

Say your job is to replace some bad brake pads.  To get to those pads, you'll also have to remove the tire and the brake caliper.  The parts that you don't need to replace for a job are usually in pristine condition, meaning that if you sell them, you'll get a much higher price for them.  All you have to do is go to the used parts store and see if they have a working caliper and tire for that car that's in okay condition (as long as it's better than red condition, it should work).  Of course, they might not have a barely working caliper or tire for that car, but they might have an exhaust manifold that will be just perfect.  So, remove the original exhaust manifold too.  As long as it's in better condition than what the used parts store is selling, you'll profit.  Sell off the originals, buy/install the used parts, and pocket the difference.  Your clueless customers will drive off happy, and you will have sold off perfectly good parts of their car for a tidy profit.

reviewText:
Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 is a game where you play the role of a mechanic with your
very own workshop/garage.

There are two modes available, Career Mode and Endless Mode, though Endless Mode isn't
available until after completing the main Career Mode.

In Career Mode you'll be given an invoice, one invoice at one time,
(There are a total of 75 in the game)
and this invoice will usually detail the job that needs done to a vehicle in question.
For example someone might want their brakes changed out.

As you play the invoices because increasingly more difficult, albeit with a little play
in them.. meaning you might be given a fairly difficult job in one invoice, then the next
one could be just changing some brakes again.

The jobs you can be give can range from changing brakes, as mentioned above,
or changing oil, air, and fuel filters, to changing the entire transmission/gearbox/clutch.

You can also test-drive vehicles, take them on a track where their braking and suspension
is tested, as well as tuning them to increase their performance.
Though I quickly tired of test-driving vehicles, since I could never see the issues that
were described in their invoices.
For example the invoice stated rattling coming from the front of the car when driving,
but I couldn't hear anything.
Or the invoice stated that steering was loose, but it was kinda hard to tell
since the steering mechanics of the game aren't the greatest.

Personally I don't have much experience with car mechanics in general..
I worked on semi-trucks for a short during in my teens, but never really learned much hehe.
However regardless of the complex nature of mechanics this game was surprisingly easy
to get into, and I found myself learning a lot.

From the way you get around in game, to how you inspect parts, both with in-game
visuals such as worn out parts being dirty, to the color-coded Inspect Mode;
the game was quite easy to learn and get into.

A lot of things are simplified and made easier than in real life..
you don't have to go scrounging around for the right sized wrench..
your jack automatically is placed under the vehicle when removing a wheel, etc.

However there's the other side of the same coin; about halfway through the game I began
to realize the game was becoming too easy.

Money was piling up and in jobs where you're supposed to be stingy and only replace a
few of the broken parts I was like 'what the hell' and replaced all the broken parts just
for the heck of it, because I wasn't concerned about profit.
Which is quite contrary to in real life.

Another thing became quite prevalent as I was breezing through the missions.
I started wishing there was more.. more everything.

By the time I completed the game I knew every part modelled in-game inside and out
and have replaced every part many times, sometimes even replacing every part in one job.
I was starting to wish I could do more complex things, and more mechanical things
in general.

This is both the games blessing and it's curse.. that you'll love the game for it's ease
of learning and it's fun factor, but then once you become a pro there's just not enough
meat on the bone.

Luckily it seems over the course of the next year or so (possibly longer I'm not completely sure) the developers are planning DLC and patches, some of the DLC I believe is free as well.
Personally, being the impatient person I am, it couldn't come soon enough, I can't wait
to see what depth will be added to the game, as it can only improve upon it.

Overall this game was a great experience, taking me 16 hours to complete the main
campaign, and though there's still Endless, I have a general feeling of
'been there done that' when it comes to replacing any parts in the car at this point.
Though at the same time if there was more meat to the game I'd be gulping it down
like my pet cat gulps down chicken. ;)

Sound 7.5  (Overall good sound quality, but occasional hitches/pops in the sound)
Gameplay 8.5  (Easy to learn and get into, but by the end of the game it's too easy)
Graphics  9  (In some places slightly muddy textures, but for a simulator it looks darn good)

Overall 8.5
Great experience with it's only real downside being it leaves you wanting for more.

reviewText: After reading several reviews and noticing it was on sale, I decided to give this game a try. I have a Quad Core 3.8ghz AMD, GeForce 730 2gb Graphics Card, and 8gb DDR3 RAM. As soon as I loaded up the first vehicle in the game, I experienced low framerates. I exited and changed the video settings to Quality High, Resolution 1280x720, VSync OFF, Antialiasing DISABLED (These are the same settings I use for DayZ, which gives me 40+FPS). I now have 0 drop in framerate, and the game still looks beautiful. I've been an experienced mechanic for over 10 years. I am a certified CNC Machinist, as well as a certified Mercedes-Benz Technician. I've been a gamer since the NES days. The graphics are really good, and I haven't experienced any noticeable bugs, glitches, or clipping issues. The sound is ok, but nothing to brag about. I did listen to the radio, but had turned it down 50% before I even started. I never found it to be annoying. Movement around the shop environment is pretty smooth. No issues there. The game starts every level with a worksheet that explains what the customer wants you to check for or replace. Great thing is, you can refer back to this worksheet at anytime. Most of the parts can be visually inspected without removing them, but a lot of parts can only be inspected upon removing something in front of it (i.e. a timing belt before inspecting the water pump). The electrical components must be checked using the OBD Scan Tool. You are also able to test drive vehicles in order to diagnose bad parts, and the physics are good. Right clicking the mouse opens a menu allowing you to install parts, remove parts, turn the chassis transparency off/on, and turn the parts color, such as red, yellow, and green corresponding to the condition, off/on. Some of the parts can simply be removed, others must be unbolted and bolted back on. Everything must be installed in the reverse order of removal. Yes, you can forget to install parts, but you cannot give the car back to the customer until you fix your mistakes. The game automatically checks tasks off your worksheet as you complete them. After a little over an hour of playing, I found this game to be very fun. I'm impressed that any developer would tackle a game like this, and with such detail. Don't expect it to be 100% realistic, such as every nut and bolt, accurate pricing, names of cars, etc. I don't think anyone could learn the basics of car repair from this game, but I do think someone can use this game to understand the overall concept of automotive repair. I honestly don't have anything bad to say about this game. I wish the concept of this game would've implemented on Forza, Grand Turismo, or Need For Speed a long time ago! If you're interested in automotive repair, get this game now that it's on sale.

reviewText:
So as a trained mechanic and a general gearhead, I figured I just had to pick this up.

However, after going through the first four or five jobs, I gotta say:

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
---I recommend this as a puzzle game, but not as a simulator" or educational game---
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Pick it up if it's on sale - it's fun to fiddle around with and see how fast you can find the problem. But the game is far
date: far away from simulating the really important things about being a mechanic.\nI guess if the devs implemented a few more challenges like stuck bolts
recommended: and the need to use the right amount of force (and maybe to pick the appropriately sized tools for the task)
hoursPlayed: this would be much more challenging. I'd love to see that implemented
voteText:
maybe by dragging the mouse to keep a "torque bar" in the green area or something.


Pros:
+ you get to learn about lots of car parts and what they do
+ it's fun to figure out what the problem is
+ sometimes you get one symptom with several causes - just like in real life. Very good.
+ sometimes
helpfulPercent:
you can fix parts instead of replacing them. That's something many real life garages seem to have forgotten.

So why am I giving it a thumbs down?
Well.

Some of the most basic and most important things about fixing cars are missing. The game reduces disassembly and assembly to clicking a few bolts:
- No torque requirements for bolts in sensitive places.
- No stuck bolts that you can break off.
- No need to pick the correct tool for the task.
- No caveats where order of disassembly is important because of the mechanics or the electrical systems. You're either prevented from making mistakes
votesHelpful:
or the things that would be mistakes in real life don't matter. The worst I've seen so far: I can rip out the starter without even disconnecting the battery - now there's a recipe for disaster.

Other cons:

- the real life challenge of saving time by disassembling as few things as possible in order to get to the damaged part is missing. Maybe it comes in at a later stage of the career
votesTotal: but as far as I've played
votesFunny: you can happily rip apart the whole car if you feel like it without any financial repercussions.\n\n- Different versions of the same part for different model years? Multiple vendors with different price and quality levels? Delivery times? Everything that makes the "parts" part of a mechanic's business challenging is missing."

reviewText: Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 is a game from PlayWay and Red Dot Games. You certainly play as a car mechanic, although I think the ‘simulator’ part of the title is a bit of a loose term.The game is slightly educational though. I knew the basics about the inside of a car and how it works, but I definitely wouldn’t have been able to fix one for you. I still can’t, but at least I can tell you where most of the stuff is. In CMS2014, you are tasked with fixing a stream of cars with various problems. At the start of each level, you receive a clipboard with a check list of objectives. Change the brake pads. Check the exhaust. You’re also given a note from the customer trying to give more details about what’s wrong with the car. I wasn’t sure if the poor grammar in these sections was intentional to give a sense of dealing with idiotic customers, but I fear it wasn’t. Your job is to fix the car, stamp the form, and send your customer on their merry way.Early levels are simple as your customers appear to be mechanics themselves and know exactly what’s wrong with the car, leaving you with the simple task of replacing the broken part.However, it isn’t long before someone shouts “IT’S MAKING NOISES”, and runs off leaving you to figure out what’s wrong. This is when you will have to start examining the ins and outs of the car. Damaged parts will be shown in red and must be replaced. This often means taking large sections of the car apart. Who knew it was so complicated to change part of the suspension? Maybe complicated isn’t the right word here. I’m sure it is in real life, but in CMS2014 it’s just… lengthy. You have to unscrew bolts one at a time by holding in the mouse button, but that’s about as tricky as it gets.The only barrier is knowing exactly where the part you’re looking for is when you’re trying to fix it. This is quite a high barrier when you don’t know, but each part is labelled when you mouse over it, so you’ll find it eventually.The monotony is broken every now and then when you’re asked to take a car for a test drive to test acceleration, braking, handling and suspension, but after the first drive of unresponsive handling, I wasn’t particularly looking forward to the next one.You never really feel like you’re progressing. The garage I was working in changed a couple of times suddenly, without any fanfare. It looked nicer and there were some more gadgets, but it was odd that I was plonked in there with no warning. It was as if I had walked into someone else’s garage and decided to work there for a while.Maybe you need to be a lot more into cars than I am to get something out of CMS2014. Objectively though, it just doesn’t seem like a whole lot of fun. There’s a lot in there for the price, but there’s only so much you can fix in a car, and with 75 levels in the main game, along with an “endless mode”, things become repetitive fairly quickly.Overall 6/10.

reviewText:
Had I written this before CMS 2015 appeared, I'd have recommended this because whilst it has some flaws, there's definately an engaging idea here.

Problem is, CMS 2015 smooths out of lot of the rough edges this game has - which are

Having to lift/drop the car a lot due to (rather unrealistic) restricted access/crappy ramps
Having to guess what's needed/what should be replaced for some jobs
Having to walk to a PC and navigate a LONG list of parts to order replacements (2015 adds a mobile tablet and SEARCH!)
An really annoying bug whereby the mouse isn't locked to the game in multi-monitor mode - which causes the game to minimize CONSTANTLY (the developer's solution of 'Clip Cursor' DOES NOT WORK

So what I recommend is if you're interested in the idea, 2015 is worth the extra to reduce the frustration!!

The interface/controls feel slightly awkward, but still much better than many of the other ____ Simulator" games that have been coming out recently.

It seems this software is decent at what it does, namely beign a car mechanic simulator. But if you're looking for a game, take caution - you might get disappointed. There are few minor problems here and there, but the major one for me is that the Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 seems to expect you beign an experienced car mechanic in the first place, knowing where all the parts are and what they are, and more strangely, what are the rules of playing this game.
After something like 2 hours of playing I have messed up a job by spending the money on the wrong things and it seems all I can do is to restart my career. Cancelling a job isn't an option. Oh well.
But if you are the kind of person that likes high learning curves and, most of all, fixing cars, you might just enjoy it. Perhaps even a lot?

reviewText:
This part is for the base game.
All though the game can become boring and feel like a chore I still really enjoyed it. There will be more cons then pros but I still recommend it. I know this review is a bit late seeing as how the new game is already out which looks awesome (I have yet to play it), but I finally got around to playing and beating this game. Any way here are some pros and cons I have for this game.

PROS:Can “learn” skills
Lots of puzzles (more of a puzzle game then simulator which isn't too bad)
You get a new shop as you progress (I would of preferred to have to buy the shops)
The tests you run on vehicles are pretty cool (but can become boring)
May help you learn about vehicle parts
CONS:Can become repetitive and feel like a chore
Sometimes too simple
Doesn't feel like a true simulator (more like a puzzle but still not too bad)
Not many parts some don't even get used and USED parts are pointless
Lots of parts are missing (compared to a real car)
Strange sun glare that can become annoying
Camera sometimes does not want to cooperate
No exotic cars
Very empty shop (would be cool to have coworkers working on other cars and maybe seeing customers in the lobby)
End of career kind of a let down (didn't really feel like I accomplished anything)


With all those cons I still really enjoyed the game. My favorite repair order was 42 which had you finding out what parts are missing, kind of wish more were like this.


And now for the DLC. I have not fully completed the DLC but I did try it out to get the basic idea of it.
For the 4x4 DLC I felt like it would have been better to combine it with the career mode.

PROS:New Test track for 4x4 vehicles (I thought it was pretty cool)
New vehicles
CONS:Things you learned from the main career (books skills) don't transfer over


All in all its basically the same so yeah nothing to special.


And now for the Drag DLC
I really liked this one and wish the main career was similar towards end game. They added a lot which is nice.

PROS:Shop is a bit dirtier (made me feel like cars have been worked on earlier)
New parts (instead of learning books you get a whole new store for racing parts)
New test track (drag)
You get more options when it comes to working on the car, this time its not about oh my muffler broke, it's “I need to beat this time so here's money, make it happen!”I didn't have any cons, I really enjoyed this part.

Like i said I know this review is late and I'm sure the new game will be much better.

reviewText:
A nice concept, and one I was hoping would be fun and help me learn a bit more about cars than I already knew. Sadly, the difference between the car in game and a real car is seriously just enormous. The only way this could be a solid game is if at least all of the parts of a car that aren't chassis, interior, and automatic transmission were correctly modeled and there were at least several variations to encounter, or the game at least had an interesting metagame that rewarded efficiency. Instead, it's seriously just a super simplified engine, suspension, exhaust and fuel systems, and that's it. Basically just a rough approximation of a car. You'll do the same three or four things over and over and you almost don't even need to read the scenario information, just find the grubby looking part and replace it. The game trailer says there are around 150 parts in the game, what they aren't telling you is around 130 of them are screws.

The money in-game is seriously worthless because there is no metagame, at all. None. So, no matter what you do, efficiency is irrelevant. Buying used parts is a waste of time, even good used parts aren't counted as 'good' parts for the repair. Selling off the old parts from each scenario is a pain, not to mention worthless. The diagnostic track seriously does nothing; no matter what is wrong with the car it is the same every time, you just magically know what's wrong after wasting your time driving around. Which is something you are often required to do for no reason even if you know what to fix because it's included in the scenario objectives. The music is good for about twenty seconds, after which it becomes patently awful.

Overall, the fun petered out after about two hours and eventually I realized that the game isn't ever going to get any more complex, approaching that of a real car. New garages don't matter because the car and its problems are always the same, the extra space is actually annoying. The game is more of a tech demonstration than a game, I would expect it to be nearly free, so I'm glad I got it at a significantly reduced price.

reviewText:
If you have no interest in puzzle games or working on cars, this probably isn't for you. If you have an interest in one or especially both than you might be surprised that you could enjoy something like this. And that's what this is, it's a puzzle game based on car repair. Customers bring you work orders with complaints or requests much like in the real world and you have to diagnose and repair the problem. There are 76 work orders (many of them with rather humorous descriptions) in the base game and 20 in the included offroad DLC with more to come soon.

Malfunctioning vehicles are basically the puzzle to be solved and it's a very simplistic puzzle at that compared to a real car. You don't have to be a pro mechanic to play this but some basic troubleshooting knowledge does help. Otherwise you might find yourself tearing down the entire car to find the bad parts if you're clueless where to start when someone brings you a car that has trouble starting for instance.

The repair jobs vary in length, time and complexity as you go. You can order the parts you need online at your terminal and fix some of them at your workbench to save costs and increase your profit. You can also spend money on training to increase some basic skills that earn you more money per job, discounts at the parts store and speed up disassembly and bad part identification. There is also a test track and diagnostic path that you can drive the car on to help identify malfunctioning systems.

The in game music is this terrible dubstep crap that just annoys the hell of me but thankfully it can be turned off.

You won't become an ASE certified mechanic or learn to run your own repair shop by playing this, but it's a good way to kill some time without a huge time commitment with no pressure. It's definitely worth picking up on sale at the sub $10 price point that I got it at.

reviewText:
I really enjoy this game, the only thing I can fail it on is overall realism. Some of the things inside of the engine and car are either not named correctly, do not look like that in real life, or overall do not exist. There are the following.

reviewText:
The primary objective of a simulator is to accurately recreate the feeling and control of completing an existing real world task, like driving, managing, farming, dating, etc. Obviously, not all real world tasks are entertaining, in fact, most are repetitive jobs you work day after day for a paycheck. The draw of a well made simulator is the ability to experience a career virtually that you may never have the chance to experience in real life. Sometimes this can be interesting and educational, sometimes a lot of fun, and sometimes extremely boring. It's up to the individual to decide if the simulator is fun or repetitive, which makes this genre extremely difficult to review. Do I review it based on its entertainment value alone, or how accurately it depicts the task it's trying to recreate?

The focus of this particular simulator is in the title. At the start of each job you are provided with a work order explaining what the issue is, and it's up to you as the mechanic to resolve the issue as best as you can. Generally this requires you to remove and check individual parts, and replace the ones that are damaged. If you don't know anything about cars it can be difficult to locate the issues at first, but once you fix the first ten cars or so you'll know exactly where to look for the problems and how to fix them.

Don't worry, there is no time limit or grading system to worry about here. Each job takes however long you need it to, so you never feel rushed or stressed. In fact, later on the game feels entirely too easy, since turning off the body model of the car grants you immediate visual access to most parts, and the ones that are in bad shape stick out like a sore thumb with a very different texture than the rest.

Locating and resolving the issues is very enjoyable. Removing and replacing the individual parts is very intuitive and even a little educational if you have zero experience with fixing cars. The models are easily recognizable, even though the vehicles are generic due to licensing constraints. There's even a radio in your garage to listen to while you work, though I hope in the future they provide a way to point it to your own music directory. You really do feel like a professional mechanic, which is the most important thing when developing a simulator.

As you progress through the 70+ jobs that come with the main campaign, you'll unlock new garages to work in with new tools such as the Path Tester, Workbench, and Chip Tuner. The interesting thing is, you don't really feel like you own the garage, even though it's implied. Each car that comes in is paid for in advance and you have to fix the problems as cheaply as possible to profit. Not being able to set your own prices or contact the customer after inspections seems like a missed opportunity here. There are zero management duties when it comes to running the garage. No rent or utilities payments to make, employees to manage, cleaning to be done, inventory to take, or anything else that comes with running a business like this. Car Mechanic Simulator is very focused on the act of fixing cars, and little else. That can be a good or bad thing depending on what you're looking for, but personally, I hope that these aspects will be added in later updates.

Features such as the OBD Reader and Obstacle Course seem more like novelties than required mechanics. Neither helps with diagnosing the issues with the cars, but both were required on multiple occasions for completing a work order, which is a shame. Providing more feedback from these features in the future would go a long way to improving on this idea. Even having your character mutter to himself while driving about how the car is handling would be a fantastic addition.

Car Mechanic Simulator feels like a great base for what will eventually become a fantastic simulator. I feel that the developers are on to something special, and cannot wait to see what the future holds for this franchise. If you are even a little interested in working on cars, but don't have the money, energy, or are generally against getting covered in grease, then look no further. With multiple free add-ons, and an endless mode, you'll get hundreds of hours out of this title. It does a great job of simulating the act of working on cars, so in that respect, it succeeds in its primary goal. As far as the entertainment factor is concerned, I'll let you be the judge.

reviewText:
1. Unscrew lug nuts
2. Take off wheel
3. Unscrew brake caliper bolts
4. Remove brake caliper
5. Inspect brake pads
6. Remove worn brake pads
7. Purchase new brake pads
8. Replace worn brake pads with new brake pads
9. Assemble brake caliper
10. Screw brake caliper bolts
11. Assemble wheel
12. Screw lug nuts
13. Gouge customer with $1,000 brake repair bill
14. Repeat as necessary

Now all your car repair needs can be performed from the comfort of your computer without having to get your hands dirty. You can perform battery replacement, brake repair, tune-ups, replace shocks, repair a clutch, change the oil, fix the suspension, and so much more!

reviewText:
Working in the after market automotive industry I thought it worth my while to check this simulator out.  First of all I recommend this product not because it actually captures the essence of being a auto mechanic but because I felt this was an innovative concept worthy of people's attention. This game only introduces you to the very basics of being an auto mechanic

I think that this simulator is a good bases of a game, but if the developer does not add levels of complexity in future versions I would not be willing to purchase in the future.  It would be a shame if the developer simply changes the look of the garages, adds a few cars and slaps a 2015 on the title.

Being a mechanic is more than just diagnosing problems, taking parts off, and than putting them back on.  Imagine you are a mechanic and you have eight vehicles needing repaired with one bay and all eight customers wanting their car done now.  In addition, you have to battle the different part stores trying to locate the parts you need to complete the jobs.  It is a constant juggling act and this simulator does not even touch this aspect of being a mechanic.

Further more, parts do not come off as easily as they do in this game.  Bolts seize, snap, and get cross threaded making the repair more difficult and resulting in a lot of lost time.  The time of the mechanic is very important.  The quicker the mechanic can complete the job the faster they get paid and get the next vehicle in their garage.  Mechanics receive their pay through their labor which is determined by the amount of time it takes to reasonably complete a repair job.  If a repair job takes longer than expected the mechanic loses money and has an upset customer.  This is also not captured in the simulator.

This simulator does not let you misdiagnose a problem.  mechanics screw up all the time causing themselves lost time trying to fix the problem and make things right with their customer.  This game does not let you advance until you have complete the entire repair job correctly.

Future versions of this game  could have a lot of potential.  If I was rating this game from 1 - 10 I would give it a 6.

reviewText:
The spiritual successor to the 1999 Mekada developed game, Gearhead Garage. If you're like me, and was a huge fan of GHG and was patiently waiting for a sequel that never materialized, I'm happy to say that you'll finally be able to scratch the itch one more time.

While Car Mechanic Simulator doesn't have as many features as I'd like, for example you can't completely tear down an engine (the block and all it's innards are inaccessible) but, there's a huge amount of features that really do a great job of simulating the act of car maintenance. Unlike Gearhead Garage where cars could be snapped back together in under a minute, things in CMS actually take time. All the bolts need to be twisted into place, parts need to be observed to determine if they're still good or need to be either repaired or replaced, and approach angles to get at certain parts that you can't reach from overhead or underneath.

You're given a garage space which you can walk around in and interact with. Turn on the radio if you like, though most of the songs are terrible dubstep beats. There's a repair bench and a computer where you can do some online shopping and buy new or used parts. There's even an rig for draining oil that you can drag into place.

In career mode you take work orders from customers who either know what the issue with their car is or just vaguely describe what happens when they drive. You can determine this yourself as well by taking the car for a test drive and seeing how it handles giving you some insight about the parts you should check.

My biggest complaint is the camera is a little sluggish and takes time to zoom in and out some times making the bolt you're trying to reach very awkward.

They are of course planning updates and expansions, my biggest of which (maybe for a future sequel) would be the ability to own and race your own cars as well as tear cars down completely. For now though, if you're a car guy or gal, considering it has zero competition, it's pretty fun. 7 / 10

reviewText:
the most unfortunate aspect of car mechanic simulator 2014 is probably its visual and functional resemblence of car building-tuning-racing classics like (prehistoric) street rod and old but more recent street legal. expectations need to be right from the get-go - this is not a game of the same building-racing genre. there is no real tuning, there is no engine swaps, there is no bodywork, you will not have your own car to work on. and that is completely fine.

this is a simulator of the somewhat boring life of car mechanic, complete with vague issue descriptions from car owners (at least in the campaign mode). and while there may be some aspects of the game that are not made in the best possible way, being true to its name is where this game undoubtedly excels.

you get access to a garage and are given a car that needs a mechanic to fix it on a given budget. rinse and repeat. there, that is the entire game.

more precisely you do get access to 3 garages over time with increasingly better interior and a different added diagnostic/tool. from start, you can test drive cars and use odb tool, with the second garage you get brakes and suspension test track and with the third - ability of chiptuning.

you can work on engine, exhaust and suspension of the car, naturally it's simplified and streamlined but works surprisingly well. the goal - diagnose and fix the car. you can either use diagnostic tools in your disposal or just look at each part manually. looking at deeper parts mostly requires dismantling to actually get to these deeper parts which will take more time and be more annoying (as it is in real life). state of parts can be highlighted with colorcoding from green to red which will be very helpful to give a good overview.

campaign consists of 75 broken cars with predetermined scenarios with descriptions sounding from serious to hilarious and i recognized more than one that i myself have given to a car mechanic. you will also get a list of (vague) objectives that you need to complete. you can also play endless more which is mostly the same but with no worded issue descriptions and generally goal being fix all the broken parts". in both campaign and endless
date: you can level up 4 aspects of yourself which ultimately make things just faster - not significant but this provides some very welcome bits of convenience.\n\nnow
recommended: to the not-so-good side of things
hoursPlayed: in no particular order:\n- detection of parts to be fixed is rigid. a broken part must always be replaced with new
voteText: 100% part. understandable
helpfulPercent: but very annoying. say you need to change a wheel. you may have taken off two wheels and one looked good enough at 98% and you bought only one new wheel. if you happen to put that 98% to where a new one was supposed to go it will not count as fixed.\n- coupled with the previous point
votesHelpful: used parts store is much more trouble than its worth and after a couple failed attempts i stopped looking at that completely.\n- camera

reviewText:
Buy Car Mechanic Simulator

I think this is best way to start my review i have played my fair share of simulators on and off Steam and Car Mechanic Simulator is one i have been craving for very long time i have been around and working on cars since 12 years old so i have good knowledge of cars and there workings.

First appearance of the game when we start up is clean and simple which are good but some option need to be added which they will in upcoming patch.

We start career mode and get under way graphics are good for simulator maybe little heavy on the reflection nice chrome texture we get first job you have job sheet which gives you rough idea what issue maybe and you need to find and fix this issue in start this can be little tricky but there are some things you can use to help make game play easier with high lighted parts etc

Controls are very nice and smooth once setup feel great no major issues

Test drive mode is low on scale but does help in sourcing the issues same with the scanner etc

mission do slowly get harder and harder but for some people they might find it repetitive but i liked it its not to hard so some one with no car knowledge could play it

It took me around 20 hours to complete the game which is good for simulator and developers have been more than helpful when facing an issue and im looking forward to DLC and possible 2015 version its a game which as lots of space to grow and become bigger i hope the developers run with that and build on what they have.

Some people wont like the game and some will and for what the game is the price is right

my rating is 10/10

reviewText: Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 is a very basic representation of automotive repair, you really need to have at least some interest in automobiles or an interest in being a handyman to find enjoyment in this game. You'll delve into the life of an automotive mechanic, starting out in a basic shade tree" style garage and work your way into more professional garages
date: which is a neat.\n\nThe depth of which the game delves into auto-repair in my experience with the game so far
recommended: has been very basic; but a couple steps above "Gearhead Garage" of yester-year. If you aren't very knowledgable in the automotive service arena
hoursPlayed: you might find this game entertaining in it's own right.\n\nHowever
voteText: if you are knowledgable with cars and car repair; you're going to find yourself pointing out flaws in the details of this game. For example: The lower suspension arm on the cars in game doesn't look like it would work because only one side that mounts to the chassis is designed to pivot while the other side is a solid mount. And $200 oil changes.\n\nBeyond that

reviewText:
I bought Car Mechanic 2014 last year and thought it was going to be a great game to try since I like to work on cars in real life. My laptop and desk top PC could not handle the graphics so I couldn't play it. I kept the game in hope to get a better PC that could run the graphics. It was worth the wait! I got a gaming PC and played the game with complete enjoyment.
The game did crash a couple of times at first but was fixed with the latest updates and works like a charm! I stayed up last night and finished all 76 orders in career and 4x4 and now am working on the tuning. Oh by the way, you get a very cool car when you finish all the orders in career! I took it for a test drive and it is fast! Loved the suprise! Now I have unlimited play unlocked and may never sleep again, lol!

If your going to get this game, which I highly recommend, make sure your gaming device (PC or Laptop) can handle it! Check the  specs for details!

You start out small in a hole in the wall garage and work your way up to a nice fancy garage with a test path and a dyno to do chip testing so you can boost up the HP (horse power) of the car! There is a way to set up the chip without just clicking the + or - countless times to get that perfect setting. I figured it out after a few tries when I noticed how they move. You'll see what I mean when you play it.

Another feature I like is the test track outside the garage! The career track is straight forward marked off with cones that you try not to hit to complete each of the 4 test runs. The 4x4 has the same test track but with mounds of dirt to really test the suspension and can be very hard to controll but do-able if your careful. Then the tuning track which is a straight 1/4 mile track to test the cars for drag racing, which by the way has it's own upgrades in the garage to buy to boost HP. Love that!

I have had no glitches in the game play at all since the updates and really enjoyed my time playing it! 2 thumbs up!
This game is worth the money you pay for it!

The Career mode is much longer than what you would expect, after 4 or 5 hours I am still not finished or bored. There is an endless play mode, too.

I'd recommend this game for those who enjoyed games like Street Rod or Gearhead Garage.

reviewText: Incredibly dull and repetitive after the first few cars. It's the exact same car for 20 levels then the same one for another 20, and all you do is buy a part, spend 5 minutes hovering your mouse over bolts with no variation in routine, and replace it (and occasionally save a few bucks by pressing x to repair a part instead). reviewText:
I was really expecting more from this game, arguably too much, perhaps, but still. There are multiple elements of the game which while they exist, seem to serve no other purpose other than a tick box to check. In particular I'm referring to the Test Drive and/or Diagnosis Path, which no matter the problem with the car, is just a short series of actions to do before returning to the workshop essentially none the wiser of the problem as it plays out the same every single time.

This, however, doesn't even present a problem as once you've had 5 minutes of gameplay, you quickly see that the whole repair is simply a case of looking for the grubby/rusty looking part, removing it and replacing it. You barely need to look at the description at all.

As others have also said, the gameplay is just simply not deep enough to be challenging or rewarding in any way. Just plays out as a time sink with little to no pay off.

Thankfully I picked this up for very cheap in a sale, but definitely not worth full price and wouldn't consider it a sim" at all."

reviewText:
Very interesting game for people who either have basic knowledge about cars, or trying to learn about it. I suppose it's really possible to find a solution for every mission by checking every single part on the car and replacing it but this would be quite boring and mundane so I really don't think it's for people who are clueless about the thematic. Sometimes customer has an idea what's going on and tells you straight up, sometimes they just want you to repair all the damaged parts and it can be difficult to narrow down the last part or two that need repair/replacement.

In terms of reality/simulation it's definitely simplified but the game is featuring all basic parts and especially the usual suspects that mechanics are dealing with. A lot of missions are based on changing oil, filters, or timing but then again I guess this is most common in reality as well.

Progression is such that you start in a basic garage, and as you work through the missions you gain access to better garage with additional tools for tuning vehicles. You can also shop for upgrades (faster unbolting, discount at parts shop, etc.)

I would add that on graphics side it's really well done, the parts look very realistic. Damage can also be observed visually, for example worn rubber, or corroded metal can indicate that part needs replacement before even checking it out.

One negative that I would mention is lack of absolutely any kind of help or tutorial system - you're completely on your own. I guess this can really put off a number of people who are not really familiar with all of this.

reviewText:
First and foremost, this game is by no means anything but what it claims to be.  Don't expect uber racetracks or incredible realism when you take the car out for a test drive.  It's a mechanic game, after all.  With that being said, this game is not an accurate depiction of working on a real car (as many, many other reviewers pointed out).  It does, however, feel like a good approximation in terms of where a video game should go without overcomplicating or oversimplifying the game.

If you're a real automotive mechanic, then you already do this kind of stuff enough, and don't need to buy this game.  If you're a realism nazi, then don't buy this game...or any video game...just go do real world stuff.  If you're looking for a game with uber fast paced acion, then this game isn't for you.  If you're someone like me who like to dink around with random game titles, then by all means, get this game at the current sale price and have some fun with it.

I honestly I shelled out 7 bucks for this product simply because this one actually featured a full demo, and seeing that in a game was worth my money. Now that I have completed the main campaign, clocking in at around 8 hours, I have to say.... sure, this was worth my 7 dollars.... but not much more than that.

I enjoyed the automotive themed puzzles, I enjoyed learning (*cough*) more about the underpinnings of cars than I neccessarilly knew before, and generally had a pleasent time with the game. However, there were several aspects of the product that caused it to suffer not only as a game, but as a 'simulator'.

reviewText:
I was really impressed by the fact that you can drive the cars, since I originally thought it was just fixing them in the garage. It is realistic to a point but way simplified, so if you know nothing about mechanics (like me) it's not an issue. Gameplay can get a tad repetetive at times, but I find a feeling of satisfaction when you know exactly what the problem is, can quickly fix it and get your payout and move on to a more challenging job.

PROS-
-Addictive, interesting gameplay
-A variety (albeit small) of environments
-Job satisfaction
-Fun problem solving

CONS-
-After a while, gameplay can get repetetive
-You can find yourself spending ages on one job, because you just can't figure out the problem.
-Some jobs are not specific enough, the might say find the problem" and you also have to fix/replace all the parts to do with the problem
date:
which was not clearly explained.
-Driving mechanics are not brilliant
-Controls can be fiddly when examining the car.

OVERALL RATING: 7/10"

reviewText:
I haven't finished it yet, but so far I'm not at all disappointed.

Pros:
Even better than Visible Engine.
It does a really great job of showing the basic mechanics of a car.
The symptoms seem to correlate well to the solutions, but I'm no mechanic.
I'm actually motivated to do some work on my own car now that I have a better idea of how things fit together.

Cons:
I think my mechanic is drunk. What is with the first person interface? Is the shop on a boat?
Some of the parts are very difficult to get in view of the camera.

I'd love to see more detailed engines, some cut scenes would be nice, a project car for your mechanic to work on on the side would be cool. High performance parts.. Engine noise troubleshooting with actual sound clips would be really neat.

Overall it's a pretty great game. Well worth the 15-20 bucks.

reviewText:
I sure hope you like undoing and doing the same bolts over and over and over again because that's a good 80% of the gameplay. The different vehicles appear to have virtually identical underpinnings and most jobs start off with taking off the wheels, the brake caliper, the two brake pads and the brake disc, then repeating on the other side and on it goes.

Even for a sim enthusiast this is pretty dry stuff. There's no decision making about how to expand your business, or a choice of cars to repair, or hunting down cheap parts (well I did find cheap, worn parts on the 2nd hand market, but I wasn't able to install it in the car as they always appear to request new parts and not all of them can be repaired).

Like a regular grease monkey, you just do your job, rinse and repeat. Not fun.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I like this game. It's nothing more than a basic simulator on garage repair. It may not hold all the detail needs of work but it is a game. Your given a work order to fix a problem. On the work order is the budget amout for parts you may need. So you get to see the mechanic fustration of a small budget with a customer who wants one thing replaced and the vehicle has all thease other problems too. Some parts can be repaired on the work bench such as starters, altenator, and what not. You go through the mechanic foot steps on inspecting parts by means of trouble shooting and problem solving. Not much different than a regular car repair. Just like fixing a real car you go through the pains of having to take parts off to get to the ones you need to replace. How ever unlike a real car everything comes off perfact. The only thing I find useless in the game so far is the OBD scanner. It is sopose to trouble shoot problems depending on any failuer that is given to the on board computer from the sensors. It dose nothing but just scan and tells you nothing. And you can't hook to the computer in the shop to get a reading. Other than that its good game. Just like real Mechanic work, this game may not be for everyone.

reviewText: Totally awesome. This is the best simulation game I have ever played. It really helps your mechanical knowledge and its just fun.\nThe tutorial hints for this game a seriously small and don't give you all the details, but it does that so you can figure it out for yourself. Most entertaining car based game I have played since Next Car Game. If this simulator could put the repair and replace part options from this game, and put it into Next Car Game. That would be the best combination of mechanical and car racing/smashing ever made. It would make it very realistic, if you race with a car, and you have to replace damaged parts and wear and tear. reviewText:
For me this is not a game it is more like a basic where is game, where is the air filter, oil filter, back box for the exhaust.

I feel that this would suite children interested in been a mechanic or someone going infor there test in the UK that requires to know where to fill up the oil and give general pointers but nothing percific (people that know nothing about cars).

For me, I dont klnow a lot about modern cars but know enough to change a ball joint, cv joint and drive shaft etc, I find this game a little tad on the boring side as I know where the problems are or the area when a vaige description is given in the work chart.

I find the game is massivley lacking something as there is little challenge and as I said I think this game is more towards  children or people that know nothing about car's that may find the game a challenge.

Personally in my opinion, I was interested in this game as I thought it might give me more of a insight of whats in new cars as I was brought up with the good old carberetta and none of this modern sensor's that put up the price when a car breaks down.

As I say in my opinion the game price is a little high as my 14 year old daughter finds the game to easy and she knows nothing about cars but saying that it has made her aware of where things are in a car so its more of a early age educational tool more then a simulator.

I would rate this game in the budget type game for price like max £6, educational tool for children and people that are going for there test in the UK to know where partts are on a car like oil filter and tires.. lol

The educational aspect is the only reason I recogmend this game, if you have an idea of what your doing under the bonet of a car stay away..

reviewText: This game has potential and is quite fun to play.. For some, without basic knowlage of how a car is built up it can be quite a challange. But for us gearheads it's way to simple too stay fun for a longer time. Also it has some flaws like stupid camera handling and wobbly mouse movement. I miss more in deep functions like brand specific parts, more engine and car types and the ability to work on the engine itself. Like shifting valves, camshaft etc etc.. Also a auction house and ability to buy/fix and sell used cars would be very fun. Bodywork customization and more.. Well the Devs have a good basic product with lots of potential here but it feels kind of rushed.. I belive we will see improvements tho they seem serious! Buy it if your'e a hobby greasmonkey ;-)

reviewText: What needs to be added is radiators need work, fans that go out, heater cores, thermostat replacement, air conditioners, electrical issues.  Headlights go out as well as tail lights, blinker issues, check engine light issues, the use of the diagnostic meter in game is a joke.  Most automobiles have on board computer issues that need attention, even in dash nav, radio, and systems all tied to electrical.   Inclusive, if you repair parts at a workbench, make the workbench work like the parts computer where one actually can rebuild issues with alternators, water pumps, brake cylindars, etc...  Even a fuse box would be nice to work with as well.  What of gear boxes and transmissions?  That too could be expanded at a repair counter.  Just adding more cars is only eye candy to the game if you're only repairing the same ole things over and over again. Simulators need lots of immersion where you don't complete a game in 48 hours.  Overall its a great simulator but needs more, lots more.

reviewText: visual part damage would be an improvement, if you know youre way around a car some of the symptoms and faults can easily lead you to what basic parts are faulty.  After awhile the variety of work becomes limited.  More indepth levels involve guess work and going through every part although you only deal with bolt on engine parts as apposed to breaking down the engine to deal with the more advance workings.  There are older garage games like redline that have far more detail in building cars from the ground up and repairing salvagable cars.   Graphically the game looks nice though and would be more suitable to people unfamiliar to basic car mechanics, 6 out of 10.

reviewText:
This is my first review, I normally do not make reviews but I seen a lot of people bashing this game. This game is not need for speed, you do not upgrade cars or make them faster. It's simply a game where you repair customers cars. If you ever played gear head garage and liked it you will like this game.

The game can get old pretty quick, it becomes a puzzle sometimes repairing cars but that's what happens in real life to a mechanic.

The test track is useless and doesn't offer any real way of trouble shooting what's wrong with a car. If the clutch is bad the car still drives fine etc.

The career mode is repetitive and towards the end offers nothing except the enjoyment of fixing cars. They have only two different motors so far and I'm towards the end. You only replace basic parts on the car. Nothing internal in the engine itself just external stuff.

The game is simple and if you do not know much about cars you could kinda learn the basics from this game. I recommend this if your a car/motor enthusiast but if your looking for something on the lines of NFS stay away.

reviewText:
Fun puzzle game. Executed reasonably well. If you ever played Gearhead Garage, then you're in for a treat. It is essentialy that game, but in a modern package. It is in some cases much more realistic than Gearhead Garage. There are more aspects of being a mechanic than just assembling and disassembling cars depicted. I really liked the game, but i have few things that are less than ideal.
Unfortunately you cannot disassemble the whole car- engine is almost monolitic, there are parts of the suspension that are non interactive. Also there is no way to disassemble the body of the car.
Part of the game is test-driving a car. Unfortunately it is almost the same every time. Car drives the same way no matter what faults it has- you don't hear additional noises parts of the suspension are shot, there is no indication that steering is off or if there are problems with the ignition or anything else. The only diferences between cars are acceleration rates and interior design. It works like this- there are parts of the suspension that cannot be examined to see if they are broken unless you disassemble them or take the test drive. Also sometimes it is required by a client for you to test drive the car and there is no way around it. All these things make the test drive fun for one maybe two times, then it becomes more of a chore than fun. Thankfully test driving a car takes about 1-2 minutes, so unless you play for a long time it will not bother you much. Don't get me wrong- i absolutely like the idea of test driving a car. I just would expect it to be more consequential and let the player to figure out what's wrong with the car instead of giving him an answer.
The last thing i'm going to complain about is number car models and parts you can buy. I hope developers will add more cars and parts to the game, but now there are two different engines and i belive there are 3 types of suspension, but there are no real diferences in them beside names of the parts that were used.
To sum up- I played 6 hours and I think i saw all the content there is to see, but i cannot say for certain. What i saw so far was mostly good. If you like this type of game (which is essentialy a 3d puzzle game) you'll have a good time, but keep in mind before you decide if you are going to buy it- at the time of writing this, game is somewhat limited, there is no much variety when it comes to cars. Game is rather easy, but i believe there is almost no competition- if you look for similar things look for gearhead garage (a bit dated, but i think still playable).
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Calling it a simulator is a bit of a  stretch. When I hear the word simulator in a gaming context, I think of intracacy and attention to detail in design, and an attempt by the developer to make the experience as close as possible to the real thing (whatever it may be). That said, Car Simulator 2014 is definitely not a simulator. As others have said, it's more like a car mechanic themed puzzle game.\n\nThe gameplay is relatively simple: you get three different functions when interacting with the parts of several different cars (analyze, remove, and install). Parts on the vehicle are colour coded, ranging from red (bad) to green (good), with percentage values. You'll get repair orders, always with some description that will hint at the problem (e.g. my car won't start")
date: and then you use the tools and the aforesaid functions to solve it. You start out with a basic garage
recommended: but eventually you progress to two better shops; the second shop comes with the ability to path test vehicles (a minigame that analyzes suspension and brakes) and
voteText: a module for chip tuning vehicles in the last. In all of the shops you have the ability to take drivable vehicles on a test drive
helpfulPercent: which is yet another way to check for damage to parts without having to tear the vehicle apart - it's not very fun
votesHelpful: and a little clumsy
votesTotal:
but it gets the job done.

What I like:

* There are several different models of vehicles
votesFunny: many with different arrangements of parts (e.g. "V6" versus four cylinder
commentsCount:
4x4 versus 2wd)

* The visuals are nice for a game of such small scale

* Some progression (spend money to make bolt removal quicker
column16:
for example)

* The interface is simple and relatively intuitive: you can hide the car body and turn on a filter to show the condition of parts

What I didn't like:

* Realism isn't a big factor in the design of this game at all (e.g. an air filter will keep the engine from running)

* The number of parts is quite limited; some front-end pieces
column18: and stuff around the motor - you'll never see the inside of the crankcase\n\n* Customers don't pay for parts or labour; they pay a flat rate
column19: and your profit is what's left over after you've bought the replacement parts (or repaired the limited number of repairable ones)\n\n* Despite the limited progression above
column20:
the game becomes very repetitive

Summary:

If you're looking for a simple (if not simplistic) puzzle-like mechanic game
column21: then you might get some enjoyment out of it. But
column22: if you're looking for a proper simulation of car repair or running a shop
column23: then you may be disappointed with the limits of Car Mechanic Simulator 2014. I was hoping for the latter
column24: and I was disappointed by the limitations of the game
column25: but I did enjoy tooling around with it for a few hours."

reviewText: Nice to see a refreshingly different title but it's not entirely realistic. For example, you'd never change your oil and not change the filter at the same time and if your brake discs are worn out, you would normally change the pads with them as well. Coming from a background where I work in a parts department at a local car garage, it is easy for me to spot these little details but at the same time someone who doesn't know about cars wouldn't necessarily know to do those things.\n\nDespite these minor details, it is actually a really good way to introduce someone to how a car works because it keeps things simple enough so that it is easy to understand but goes into enough detail to make it interesting to the casual audience or people who may well be just getting interested in cars. It does end up getting a little repetitive and that may put some people off and for the petrolheads out there, some different layouts for engines/mechanics would help to mix things up a bit more but ultimately, I enjoyed this.

reviewText:
Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 is the first FPS game ever to give me motion sickness.

I only noticed I was getting nausea about an hour in, when the FPS POV I was seeing the game through wouldn't stop ♥♥♥♥ing bobbing, like I was playing as The World's Drunkest Car Mechanic. Thankfully, I was able to find a way to turn off the head sway. However, it does not stop the camera from zooming in and out suddenly like it was bobbing its head to a song I couldn't hear while I was trying to take apart the car. Need to remove the timing belt? ENHANCE. ENHANCE. That's gone, now the actuator. OH YEAH, PARTY TIME. OONTZ OONTZ OONTZ. Fix the water pump? ZOOM IN ON THAT ♥♥♥♥ LIKE WE'RE THE NSA. Unlike the sway, I cannot turn that ♥♥♥♥ off AT ALL.

It did teach me a few things about cars and I like a game that makes me use the parts of my brain involving deductive reasoning. I like to fix ♥♥♥♥ and it made me feel smart. However, this simulator skimps on a lot of the finer details of automotive maintenance and it's actually not all that good at making me feel clever when I've finally managed to fix the problem with the car. There's nothing really to gain from playing this. Especially if playing it makes people feel queasy. Don't bother.

reviewText:
For myself, someone who knows less than nothing about cars, I found this game to be fun and informative. I found the controls a bit wonky and wished I could remap some of the default directional controls, but it didn't prevent me from enjoying the experience. As I've owned the game additional features have been added so I can't say whether remapping keys is an option at this time.

The graphics are very clean and sharp, allowing one to see where the various car components are in an uncluttered transparent skeleton model. I know looking under the hood of my car certainly doesn't look remotely like this game. Where's the boundless layers of grease, rust and leaves. Why do I have leaves under my hood?

There are a few good songs that play in the game, one of which has a heavy riff guitar that I enjoy the most. The songs are basically just background music now that I've turned the volume down some. The variety of songs is varied enough to keep things from getting too stale.

I would agree with some other reviews that there is certainly some repetition to the repairs, but that's exactly why I got the game. I wanted to learn about car parts and where they are on the vehicles. So this is probably not a sim well suited for the mid to high level car tinkerers out there. I would recommend this sim game for the uninitiated auto jockeys like myself.

reviewText:
I'm yes and no on my recommendation for this game. This is the groundwork for a game I'd love. Kind of a long reading following but this'll give anyone looking into game an exact idea of what they're jumping in to. This game is a nice buy for car/mechanical enthusiasts. This game would be best set up for someone who is just getting into cars, but isn't very familiar with their mechanicals. You could learn how basic parts go together and what some of their effects may be. However, to advance through this game at a decent pace you need a little prior mechanical knowledge. For example, you may be told that you need to find a power issue and not know that the fuel pump or fuel filter could be the problem.

The problem with this game though, is that no matter whether you're a mechanic yourself or someone learning, The game will have become mind-numbingly monotonous about 3/4 of the way through. At this point you'll have seen all the vehicles, driven them, taken care of every problem, and you'll be running on repeated problems so you can buy all the Learning Book upgrades. All the concepts are presented less than halfway through the game, then the later garages simply allow you to diagnose parts faster. At the time of writing this I quit the campaign about 6/7 of the way through out of sheer boredom.

If you've ever played the 1989 Street Rod DOS/Commodore 64 game, then you've played this game. Infact, in the first garage, the game can be seen lying on one of the shelves as a neat little reference. I would recommend searching around for Street Rod, since it's a nice little game to play. The only problem is that this game only has slightly more detail than Street Rod did 25 years ago.

In Street Rod, you changed wheels and clicked the bolts much like you do here. You changed out engines, removed heads, carburetors, and upgraded your car in general. After upgrading, you'd go do a basic NES-era street race to earn other cars or money and continue until you beat the fastest racer in town.

In Car Mechanic Simulator, I'd say you have a little more variety of detail but not where most would enjoy. Put graphical detail of 3D models aside. When it comes down to it, you're changing air intakes, timing chain/belts, suspension parts, gearbox parts rarely, and the exhaust. You will never touch the engine block, the sub-frames, or any body work (on that note, the feature list specifically states that you will do body work). These parts are off-limits and can't be removed. You will never be able to customize any setup; it's Part-On, Part-Off, and what condition the part is in.

The car models themselves are nicely detailed, but are static and feel a bit bland with the way they are rendered. The cars are modeled after real-life cars, but use slightly different design and names. Most of them will be European/Japanese economy cars or small vans/SUVs. The 2010+ Mustang replica is the most distinguished car, but oddly one of the SUVs seem to the fastest car you can test drive.

As parts wear, they begin to show slight signs of rust, which is a nice detail. That said, parts are fixed. There's two engine designs: I4 and V6. The two engines are the same in each iteration, and the V6 will sometimes have a RWD dif or 4WD dif with an additional driveshaft. Also, both engines are always transversely mounted, which is a bit odd considering most V6s in this game are RWD rather than FWD.

Gameplay wise, there are a few minor annoyances. While part selection in general is nice, there are times when you'll find yourself clicking to a part 5+ times because of the cursor trying to select a part that's behind the one you want to click. Certain parts, while obviously accessible from your current position (under the car, left side wheel well, etc), can't be touched unless you exit the current area, walk around, access the proper" area
date: and then remove the part. Often
recommended: the camera will zoom or align to an impossible angle to remove the bolts you just selected
hoursPlayed: so you'll have to fiddle around and zoom out to remove the part. Occasionally
voteText: the bolt removal will glitch and you'll have to move the camera to be able to click the bolt again. You'll find yourself constantly moving between nearby areas and lifting the car up and down repeatedly to reach nearby parts. One of the bigger annoyances was the removal of air filters and exhaust parts.  To remove the air filter
helpfulPercent: you have to remove the plastic engine cover
votesHelpful: the tube
votesTotal: the MAF sensor
votesFunny: the cover
commentsCount: and finally the filter (VS just taking the cover off in real life). God forbid you have to remove the exhaust manifold or the catalytic converter. You will have to start at the back of the car
column16: removing every section of exhaust until you reach the desired part. In real life
column17: you'd either drop the whole assembly or simply remove the problem section by itself. These little things
column18: while not that big a deal by themselves
column19: can become annoying after a short amount of time.\n\nAlso
column20: never buy used parts. Just don't. Often the game requires the replaced parts be of a very high condition and often the random part will be in the green and still not be accepted as a replacement. In regards to replacement parts
column21: often you are not told what the complete requirement of repair is. While not knowing a problem is true to real mechanic shops

column24: as early on in the game

column26: a small personal gripe of my own. The game feels like a hospital bedroom. Everything feels stark and bland. Everything on the cars are perfect save for part discoloration. There's no character to any of the vehicles or the locales (save for the first garage itself). Perhaps if there was unique body damage
column28: or visual dirt/grime and broken part models it would feel a bit more lively.\n\nOver all though
column29: this is a fun game for the auto enthusiast for a few hours. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes cars and wants to learn the basic setup of car mechanicals. I feel at the current time it's more of a $10 game rather than $20. I'll have to see how the game evolves with updates
column30: but as the core game is now I'm going to let the last of the campaign sit. I want so badly to have a modern
column31: high-definition version of Street Rod or Gearhead Garage. This is a step in the right direction. I'd pick this game up to support the developers and to help show that there's a market for this kind of game."

reviewText:
This is the real deal. I mean, not literally the real deal, Car Mechanic Simulator won't leave you covered in grease or anything. Like most sims, the fundamentals of CMS are simplified--you don't, for example, have to worry about things like re-tightening the bolts on a wheel in a star pattern, and you don't have to think about what kind of oil the car takes, you just empty it and refill as needed. But the basic idea is there: figure out what's wrong with the car, identify the parts to fix or replace, and bolt the new parts into place. Simple! Or maybe not.

The first few tasks are very simple, but as the game goes on you'll run into more difficult or more vague problems. Sometimes, this isn't so great--a few of the orders, for example, want you to restore a part of the vehicle to tip-top shape, not mentioning that all parts must be green (hey, the car still drives with yellow or orange parts, and some cars come in so beat up that every part is orange, so clearly the game doesn't expect me to replace every non-green part, right?). But most of the time, the challenge is fair. Why does the engine cut out occasionally? What's causing that odd sound at low RPMs? If you don't already know the possible answers, you will soon.

There's still more the devs can do to make this an awesome game--the garage management aspects aren't very interesting, and sometimes you'll get a request describing odd behavior with the car only to find the test drive doesn't show any of these aspects (it's not supposed to, it turns out). But this is a surprisingly absorbing sim. Definitely recommended if you like the idea of tinkering with car engines without having to get your hands dirty.

+ Players see what basic auto parts in-general, look like.
+ Players also can visualize how these automotive parts mechanically fit together, and differ from other in-game parts' relative size and shape.

reviewText:
Great game, very enjoyable. If this is based on real life car maintenance, it is a great way for a guy such as myself to learn the fundamentals of maintaining my own car just in case. I am a big fan of simulators generally speaking and this is one simulator that I have never seen before. The graphics fidelity is good but not great, then again it is focused on car maintenance and not really a racing simulator where every visual has to be perfectly crisp. As a person who never touched a car bolt, it is quite fun to learn the quickest way to get to a part and replace it. Took me quite a bit of time to realise how easy it was to get the engine start part out.

However the down side to this game which I noticed, taking a car for a test drive for assessment is completely useless. Reason being that you won't be able to know what is wrong with a car just from a test drive or at least you don't receive a test drive results.

I have done a test drive before I repaired a faulty muffler, to see how loud the car goes. Did the repair and tested it again, there is no difference in engine sound. Customer said the the car is too loud because of the muffler isn't doing its job. But you can't really tell because there is no such thing.

Secondly, Suppose as a mechanic you want to save some money by buying used car parts in very good condition to use for repairs. Sorry to ruin the fun for you, you can't do that. This is because A) in-game used car parts shop does not show if a particular part is in good condition or bad.. Maybe a percentage scale??? and B) Even if you are lucky to snag a gearbox which scores 80% out of a 100% with a really good price tag, you replace the old damaged gearbox and Job done? No, the game does not allow you to do that and you wont be able to progress to the next job.

I hope this review reaches the game dev team to make it better in future updates.

Will I recommend this game to friends or simulator enthusaists? Answer is yes, despite those little quirks in the game but I do agree I personally found it fun to play and this is just starting out, did not reach the point where I do complex jobs and tweaking engine power using power commander etc.

reviewText:
Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 is quite fun if you enjoy pulling a car apart and attempting (in my case) to find parts to remove where you havn't really any idea where to look! A few logisitics here and there, for example, to work out how to change a clutch.. Removing certain parts around it to find the problem.

Although the test drive phsyics and mouse movement are something to be questioned and get used to, it is in all a simple yet enjoyable simulator which addresses an area of the game market which is very much neglected.

Graphics (especially for game type) 9/10
Game Concept 8/10
Playability (so far) 7/10
Understanding (straightfoward) 8/10

Overall 8/10

*Would highly recommend if you thoughly enjoy unscrewing blots*

reviewText: In this simulation/social commentary Vidcon, you play as the owner of a GARAGE who must repair AUTOMOBILES to make ends meet. Without a formal education or any experience in AUTOMOBILE repair, you must take out a loan to finance both your business and your training. However, if you choose poorly, you will find yourself in the red- unable to pursue both options. Which will you choose: future opportunity or present stability? Will you cut corners to keep your nascent GARAGE afloat? Will you end up penniless, forever trapped in a greasy dubstep purgatory? All these questions are answered... and more... in CAR MECHANIC SIMULATOR TWO-K ONE-FOUR!
