reviewText:
It's one of a kind, you will have your own workshop, you get an contract to repair a car, at the beginning you get simple problems to fix and the worn out part is mentioned in the contract.

After that you get much complicated problems, customers will only give you the symptoms and you will have to find the worn out part that causes the problem by your own, it might be more than one part.

This game is really amazing and it won't be everyone's choice because like any other simulation game it has a certain fanbase.

If you are much into cars and parts stuff and have a good knowledge about mechanics and want to test your skills, this game is for you!

I've got expierence in my previous car that i had in REAL life, and it seems that the bad days i had with it payed off now in this game :p

Have a nice time playing this game, and I hope the developers will go deep with this game, more details more costumization to your workshop, competition with other workshops and so on would be very nice to see in the game.

7/10 , one of the few games i spent more than 5 hours playing in late 2013, and 2014.

reviewText: While it isn't precisely the same as working on real cars in a real garage, Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 does bring more of the look and feel of working in a real commercial garage than one would expect from a simulation.\nThe engine work is greatly simplified (ignition problems are limited to but a few components, simulated cars never seem to suffer from any issues related to the internal workings of the motor) but the intake, suspension, exhaust and driveline (including, diabolically, the clutch/pressure plate/clutch-release bearing) are detailed enough to get the feel of in-shop assembly and disassembly.\nI really enjoyed playing through this game, and the 4x4 expansion. I hope that further expansions will add more detail to the magic-box style gearbox and engine internals... Maybe even add a gas/electric hybrid into the mix, too.

reviewText: Car Mechanic Simulator Complete Edition is a quite roundup representation of a modern garage shop, its tools and procedures (later on). The majority of the jobs (tasks) require you to solve some mechanical or other problem to complete the job, which becomes harder and more complex as you advance. But the whole car experience is presented well enough, even for people without the know how of the inner workings of a car, e.g. its engine, electrics, suspension etc to be able to grasp and visualise each aspect quite clearly from earlier on. No need for a manual either, as the examine tool is enough to help you identify the majority of the problems in earlier jobs. The knowledge can then be used later on in the game to solve more complex (or vague) faults having learned by now where to look (if only it was that easy in real life!).\n\nThe release of Car Mechanic 2015 has improved almost every aspect of the 2014 one but hasn't reduced it's worth. Mostly the improvements are over small niggles which we were used to anyways, such as lack of achievements, multiple jobs, the annoying auto zoom in/out of the examined part, inventory sort, lack of keybinds, cursor slip in window mode, etc etc Also the 2 addons included in the Complete Edition"
date: the "4x4" and the "1/4 mile" add little value overall and should have been included in the main game
recommended: as they are just distractions overall.\n\nI would recommend Car Mechanic Simulator Complete Edition to anyone that likes puzzle games as almost all the jobs given require you to investigate an existing car fault(s) and fix them as cheap as possible. Also would recommend to anyone that wants to learn about the anatomy of a car as a learning tool
hoursPlayed: as it does demonstrate quite accurately some of the main aspects of a car
voteText: which otherwise would need to spend a long time in a garage to visualise.\n\nAnd with the 75%-80% off sale this week from steam
helpfulPercent: makes this a worthy addition to everyones' library."

reviewText:
Well this is an interesting one.
It is a puzzle game wrapped up in a car mechanic wrapper. Easy, at your own pace kind of action. Really interesting.

While it will not really teach you how to fix a motor or a car in general. It does help illustrate some of the Anatomy of a vehicle in general and the essence of disassembling and replacing parts. For example, if you need to replace the clutch, you can't just pull the clutch out. You have to remove the wheels and axels and starter. Then you can get at the transmission and clutch.

The driving system is a bit overly sensitive (when using a keyboard) and the controls are a little under defined, but overall a really interesting, relaxing puzzle game

reviewText:
I LOVE THIS GAME! I own an automotive shop in Austin, TX and this game is very simple and enjoyable. I could play this game endless of time. This game reminds me of the game called GearHead Garage with Snap-On which was the coolist game to play in the past on PC and its almost similar to this game I played. I don't consider this game to be perfect... yet but looking forward to see this game grows with more adds, parts, vehicles.

I wanted to say that the first time playing this game was a bit arkward with the camera and how to play but after a few vehicles repaired, I got the hang of it. Its very easy and fun game to play. I hope they consider adding Professional Mode where we could do more deep repairs and diagnostic like in real life. When you see the loading picture of the internal transmission parts, that is what I'm looking forward to see in Professional mode or such like replacing knocking piston by wrist pin or connecting rod bearings or etc. Hopefully they will develope one.

Anyone whos into automotive work should consider buying this game, again some of you might or might not like it but it's not for everyone. Its a lite verison for now but I believe they will grow to develope more to add this game. This game felt some-what repeative but that's the same concept of automotive work in real life and it doesn't bother me.

reviewText: Probably one of the most innovative games I've played in a very long time. I can not describe the overwhelming feeling of joy I felt when I saw that beautiful Prius sitting in my shop, waiting to be operated on. MY shop. reviewText: This game pretty much nails the very basics of being in the automotive industry, though there were a few annoying details like not actually getting able to strip an Engine apart and adjust crank position or anything heavy like that. As far as heavy goes it's just Chip Tuning. I'm not exactly clued up on car mechanics since I mostly work on motorcycles but a lot of what is in this game allowed me to refresh and remember key basics. I could honestly play this game all day and I seriously recommend it to anyone who is just starting to do mechanics or to someone who already knows about mechanics as a small refresher.

reviewText: The idea is good, very good, but way to far to be called a simulator... The most simplest job in the game is changeing brake pads on a disc brake system. In the game all you do is... 1. take the wheel off 2. take the caliper off 3. remove the pads from the brake rotor 4. Replace the old pads with new pads 5. Reinstall the Caliper 6. Put the wheel back on. In real life this is the basics, but so far from the actual thing, its great for the casual gamer who dosen't know anything about cars, but when you do this stuff for a living its somewhat silly and mundane. If your wondering how many steps their actually is to replace the brake pads in real life... 1. Break all lugs on wheels 2. Jack car up 3. Remove all wheels 4. Disconnect all brake lines from calipers and allow time to bleed off. 5.  Remove calipers 6. Remove brake pads from Caliper 7. Compress cylinder within Caliper to allow new Pads to fit 8. Install new pads to fit 9. Reinstall all Calipers with Pads 10. Not a bad idea to check the rotors as well, Replace if worn or galded 11. Reconnect brake lines to all Calipers 12. In respect to the posistion of the Master Cylinder start from the farthest corner and work inwards bleeding the calipers to fit, make sure no air is in the lines. 13. When bleeding your Brake system pump your brake pedal and depress on the third pump, while another person cracks the bleeder on the caliper, repeat until clear fluid is coming out. 14. Frequently check the Master Cylinder to ensure it is not empty when you are bleeding the brake system. 15. If everything checks out, put your wheels back on and torque them to their respective torque rateing.  But in all honesty, if the game did this i would be impressed, and probably not want to play, that sounds like a lot of work. There are also some things that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off, like stupid ♥♥♥♥ that your best position to remove a starter is from the top of the engine compartment, and rubber bushings just slide out, and even the fact that everything you do is by hand with a wrench. Not going to lie, i like this game, i suggest you buy it if you wanna get some general car knowledge, but this thing is far from a simulator.

reviewText:
Summary:

Generally a terrible game.

The Why:

Purchased on the Steam sale for a low price but even that can't justify the headache this game creates. As the blurb says you run a car workshop, carrying out orders to test or repair customers cars.

Unfortunately, even if you over look the base graphics and the eyestrain inducing distance blur (it renders a workshop and despite this small space it blurs walls and details out when you walk too far away) the meat and potatoes of the game is sadly lacking.

From a mechanically point of view the game is very basic, almost child like in the way the disassembly and assembly of the car and components occur. It's very much by the numbers and sometimes incorrect (good luck installing a helical spring into the car before the shock assembly) or removing a wheel without jacking the car up or using the car lift or even removing wheel nuts in the correct manner or any sort of torquing.

From running the workshop point of view the business side of it is sadly lacking, I repaired a starter and charged the customer $100. Repairing the starter cost $92, so I made $8 on that job not including my time, any consumables, taxes or running of the workshop itself.

The UI is terrible, the camera controls frustrating and the restrictions on how you can inspect components irritating. Test drive is pointless.

Perhaps a good game to get a young child interested in car mechanics but I would not recommend for anyone else especially anyone who has actually tinkered with cars themselves.

reviewText:
While I love cars, this just wasn't the best game I've seen.
My one main problem with the game is the repetitiveness (is that a word?). There's some variation, but it's mostly- Find red parts (Sometimes through a test drive), replace, next mission. It would be fine if there was some sort of way to move through the game other than buying books for faster screwing.
Another problem was the interface. I was hoping more of a simulation, but that wasn't there. Instead of a visual damage (Which would be nice in a Simulator) the part is just regular, yellow, orange or red colored, which is headache inducing at times. Also, while I was hoping for a mechanic's view, it's just a camera with wierd controls. This makes taking out bolts and small parts very repetitive and boring.
Overall, I can't really reccomend this game, as it lacks both the gameplay elements of a game, and the realism of a Simulator.

reviewText:
- Laggy input.
- Floaty camera.
- No FOV (Field of View) setting
- No way to go back to the options menu after starting the game.
- No way to fine-tune video settings (e.g. I want high-quality textures and anisotropic filtering; and low-quality other stuff).
- No borderless-windowed mode.
- No way to filter/search in the in-game simulated web browser.
- No shortcuts to in-game actions: assemble, disassemble, examine conditions, show conditions.
- Inconsistent input: going back sometimes requires right-clicking, other times requires pressing Esc.
- During test-drive, it looks like the white light for the reverse gear does not work. I even thought I was a defect with the car, but I don't think I can replace them.

Laggy input, low framerate, floaty camera that keeps moving too much... All these contribute to make me feel dizzy in the first few minutes of the game.

I cannot recommend a game like this.

reviewText:
CMS14 isn't going to make you a real life mechanic overnight. It's not a true simulator, but it's more of a puzzle game. In the early part of the game, you are already given the areas that need to be fixed, and it's more like unbolting parts, fixing them, and rebolting them and finishing the mission. You are given several basic situations of what to fix in a given situation. Later on though, like a real mechanic, the customer will only give a general situation, and it's your job to figure it out. Pretty much anything that is red, you have to fix.

I think the only negative is probably the variety of parts to fix. All cars have (more or less) the same parts, like the engines all look the same. Things like supercars with turbos aren't in the game, as are aftermarket parts. Everything is a FWD car.

If you like puzzles and you like fixing cars, this is a good game for you

reviewText:
An astoundingly relaxing title for those who enjoy a little logical problem solving wrapped up in a neat little educational package. At no point could the game be considered a replacement for a formal mechanical education, but as you progress through job after job a little common sense goes a long way, and patterns emerge as you learn to associate particular faults and issues with components. While this will not help you put together that kit-car you’ve promised yourself for 20 years, it will give you an insight into the likely causes of common problems and test your ability to narrow down the offending item.

Reasonably priced, well-polished for its price point and even a little educational – a very reasonable product indeed for anyone who wants to get a feeling for the causes of common car problems, or if you just enjoy a little problem solving.

reviewText:
CMS14 isn't going to make you a real life mechanic overnight. It's not a true simulator, but it's more of a puzzle game. In the early part of the game, you are already given the areas that need to be fixed, and it's more like unbolting parts, fixing them, and rebolting them and finishing the mission. You are given several basic situations of what to fix in a given situation. Later on though, like a real mechanic, the customer will only give a general situation, and it's your job to figure it out. Pretty much anything that is red, you have to fix.

I think the only negative is probably the variety of parts to fix. All cars have (more or less) the same parts, like the engines all look the same. Things like supercars with turbos aren't in the game, as are aftermarket parts. Everything is a FWD car.

If you like puzzles and you like fixing cars, this is a good game for you

reviewText:
CMS is great if you want to grasp some basic automotive knowledge. And I do mean it. If you, like me, were seeking for challenges and in-depth content, then maybe this game is not for you. Here's why:

1. It's too easy and repetitive.
The first assignments will feel fresh and may be fairly challenging if you haven't had any experiences with car maintenance. After a while however, 2 hours in my case, the game gets boring. Problem searches become extremely easy as bad components will be very obvious to spot. This is also due to how the cars are built; every single car has almost everything put in the exact same place. Even GM couldn't pull that off.

2. It's way too simple.
There are no rusty nuts and bolts, anything can be taken out with a simple wrench, because, what are ratchets? You never have to appy oil, silicone grease and whatsoever. Basic car programming tasks are completely absent. There are also no customers that would pressure you, make work difficult, etc. (conversations would be nice). The only thing that requires you to actually do more than pressing LMB and RMB are freaking oil changes, but even those get repetitive after a while.

3. Not enough content.
Another problem of CMS is the little depth of content. You never have to pay for garage bills, every car has unlimited supplies of headlight fluids, the wrenching upgrades do not offer enough and, like I said before, no angry customers and competition. The biggest problem for me however is the lack of variety in cars; You can't find a diesel car, truck and anything that doesn't have its engine up front. So, if you ever wanted to do some car projects that would make you insane in real-life such as an V8 Audi or even Kim Jong-il's Merc 600, look away.

Verdict: CMS is alright for anyone that wants to get a very general understanding of car maintenance. But then, you will have to shell out 6 or 12€ for a so-called simulator that makes car maintenance and engineering look as simple as a Volkswagen Beetle engine. There are thousands of literature and internet sites with more depth that are dedicated to these topics. Most of them don't even cost you a penny. If only the game offered much much more in terms of entertainment value, I wouldn't mind recommending it.

reviewText:
Not a bad base game. Kept me occupied for a while but is a limited experience with less replay value compared to the old Gearhead Garage game that I remember fondly.

The entire game suffers due to long load screens between the garage and different test areas

The main negativity comes with the two expansions.

The offroad expansion adds little apart from some new vehicles and a tweaked test track, while being littered with multiple spelling errors and occasional broken orders. Order 13 broke for me and seems to be an ongoing unfixed problem for some on forums.

The 1/4 Mile expansion becomes repetitive extremely fast. The early orders I played simply set a time to beat and I just buy and fit enough tuning parts to beat said time. I quickly lost interest and stopped playing this mode. There are two big problems apart from the repetetiveness  with this expansion for me:

1. Due to hitting the drag strip after each upgrade I spent most of my time staring at the load screen (seems to take nearly as long as the drag test itself).

2. The learning book upgrades unlocked in the career mode are not implemented in the 1/4 mile version so despite being in the endgame garage, changing parts takes a long time as though I'm back at level one. The skills should carry across from the completed career mode in my opinion.

Overall, worth picking up on sale to play through the career mode and then move on, maybe dabbling with endless mode if you get the itch to play some more. Forget about playing the expansions in their current form because they add little, while having drawbacks and bugs. I cannot recommend buying this at standard retail price.

reviewText:
Dumb.

As an actual mechanic, i expected it to be far less complex than car repair actually is... but i never imagined it being this bad. The job where you have to do an obd scan on the car, i thought alright lets see whats wrong going on......doesnt even give errors or any info, scan complete, job done, same money as replacing a starter? Taking the intake mainfold off is just one click, but i have to wrench 4 bolts out of the airbox? Able to remove the fuel filter, which was located betweeen the fuel tank and body of the car, without removing the tank?

I realize that if the game were too in depth it would be too hard and boring for most people. But i think a happy medium is needed and this is far from it. Neglects to mention simple things that people should know like lug pattern tightening. Guy says needs air, oil, fuel filter changes... changing the oil filter but not the oil? When you need new parts for a car, no looking up making sure you get the right parts, all parts fit every single car. Spare parts laying around fit every car. Hit it with a hammer, brand new again.

I paid $1.69 for this game and im not even gonna request a refund since i got 54 minutes time waste outta it. Still i dont think its worth paying money to play. In fact even if they offered me money to play it i would still probably decline.

reviewText:
Story
No real deep story, only thing you know is that you are a car mechanic with your own shop. You start off in what looks like your garage and then move on to bigger places as you get more money and more customers.

Gameplay
It handles nicely, sometimes the controls can be a bit bulky. You get a car, the customer tells you what is broken or what he thinks is broken and then you fix it. The way you do that is by examining parts and determining which ones need replacing or servicing. You can do all kinds of tests to see how the suspension is, how the engine is, how the tyres are and so on. You can change just about any part of the car and engine.

You can even drive the cars on a closed course to check brakes and stuff, but the handling is really poor, almost farm simluator poor. And even though let's say the brakes are almost non existent when you checked, it brakes fine on the driving course, same with traction and speed, it's always the same no matter how broken the car is.

You can magically reach into the car after removing some parts that are in the way, so you can after removing a lot of stuff for example change the flywheel or gearbox even. You would think that it will get repetitive after a while but as you progress further into the game you are completely on your own in trying to find what the problem is, you might only know that when I accelerate there is a clunking sound from the eninge" or something. You can also tune cars and try to make them go faster on a dragstrip

reviewText: Looking to fill the hole that Gearhead Garage left? Well, this game kinda does it... but not completely. The engine rebuilding is very similar and you can repair damaged parts and buy used parts but as far as I have seen so far there is no auction block (my favorite part of GhG), no body damage and no upgrading vehicles. reviewText:
Awesome game, get it while it is on sale. I have learned alot about cars, was up till 6am playing.

EDIT: After reading the other reviews I just had to stand up and defend this game. Let me start by saying that I know almost NOTHING about cars. The learning curve is not that steep. The missions slowly step you up to higher levels of knowledge. I only almost" got stuck once. Now they added a resart mission button though. There IS 4X4 and V6. Now I want it to be MORE complex. I have learned alot. After a repair sometimes I wikipedia the parts I replaced and as a result my knowledge has gone up.


To sum it up

Per la versione italiana scorrete sotto!

Premise: Don't look at my gameplay hours, I had the DRM free versione and imported the savegame.

Car Mechanical Simulator 2014 is one of the few game in the Simulator jungle that keeps his head up without looking like a 2 cent program made to lure people.

Gameplay:
You are a mechanic and in the story mode you will start in your little workshop. You will receive orders from the costumers and you will have to find the problem by investigating and/or disassembling the car, then fix it..
At start you can only do a little test run with the car (other than disassembling it piece after piece), then you will unlock the diagnostic center and the chiptuning.
The structure of the mechanical parts is a good compromise between detailed and Let's not freak out who doesn't do this job"
date:
the only flaw: Almost nothing change between different cars model.

Game engine:
Do not expect too much from that
recommended: it's not made to amaze you. It has a simple graphic
hoursPlayed: you will never see your character
voteText:
when driving a car it feels really "arcade". Music and sound are minimal as well.

Conclusion:
Even if it's a little repetitive and I hated the quarter mile addon (the 2 DLC are included in the steam version) I suggest you to buy it even if you are slightly interested in the subject.
It's well done without being too demanding and it's quite cheap (even better when discounted)

---------------------------------------

reviewText:
This is one of the best car mechanic sims I have played but, it can become redundant after awhile.

Initially there are lots of different jobs to perform and it actually requires you to remove screw after screw and seperate components to get to the innards of the engine, suspension etc. You have to order or repair parts after diagnosing what the problem is and replace the proper part. Overtime, this can be repetitive because there are only so many parts and always the same problems with each car.

Overall, it is interesting at first and a well made game but, it becomes quite boring quickly.

reviewText:
I purchased Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 for less than $4. I’ve played a good 17 plus hours so far. For less than $4, I got my money’s worth. At full price however, I don’t think it’s really worth it.

For one, it is very unrealistic. You can’t rebuild an engine in this game or even replace one.

They have a used car part option to save money, but it is completely useless. Often times, I buy a part from here only to either sell it back because it is damaged/broken or the game wants you to buy a brand new one instead; but you don’t find that out until you reassemble the car back together only to see that the checkmark box on the paper is still unchecked. Only a very few times it was necessary but that was far in between and you waste a lot of time (trial and error) in doing so.

There is a progressive system but it’s pretty basic. There are only four things to level up: your tools (to unbolt things quicker), business management (to increase money after each fix), better mechanic (at the start, a few parts will already be checked for you), and price discount on parts (new parts costs less with each level up). Each category can be leveled up ten times and then it maxes out.

There is a bank loan option but I have never used it. I never needed to borrow money during my time of play. All I did was found the part that needed repair; repaired it or bought a new one and replaced it and pretty much did the minimal until the checkmark box was checked. I didn’t go the extra mile and replaced parts that were in yellow or in orange because that would be wasting time/money.

Overall, the game is repetitive and does get boring after a while. The game starts you off with some easy fixes then it gradually progresses into harder or multiple fixes. Sometimes, the problem is given to you very broadly like “the engine won’t start, find the problem.” Other times it is given to straight forward, “change my oil.” You get three things that help you test most of the parts like the suspension, brakes, starter, alternator, etc. There are four colors that each part will display to determine its wear: green, yellow, orange, and red. Green means the part is new or in excellent condition. Yellow means it is okay. Orange means it is about to go out (does not mean you need to replace it though). Red means it’s worn out or broken and needs to be replaced. All you have to do, to be successful in this game, is replace the red parts and ignore the rest. Viola! I’ve had four garage upgrades (they upgrade by themselves after doing a number of fixes for each garage). I’ve maxed out all my upgrades (level 10 in each category). If I had to give this game a grade it would be a B-. It’s okay, but it could be a lot better.

reviewText:
Hey guys,

I have 5 hours or so on the clock for this droll lil game called Car Mechanic Sim! I personally know next to nothing about cars, and while awaiting Dragon Age's impending release, I needed to kill a few hours and I thought I'd learn a lot from the game.

What I got out of it:
* I know a LOT more about car parts and their location.
* I have a basic grasp of replacing car parts.
* I got more enthusiastic about cars.
* I had a fair amount of fun for a few hours.

What I did not get out of it:
* An intuitive interface (it's quite cumbersome and the camera is dreadful).
* Knowing how to tell when a part is bad.
* Learning what different parts do.
* Really finding out  how to do it (the game has a necessary level of superficiality).

All-in-all not a terrific or extremely realistic simulation, with actually pretty poor controls and very little in the sense of helpful tips or tutorials, but for the few bucks I spent on it, I do feel I learned a lot of useful things and I had fun learning them!

reviewText: For the first couple fo hours playing the movement of the camera actually caused vertigo. By slowing it down I was able to begin t enjoy this game it IS a modern update of Gearhead Garage but without the ability to buy cars to fix up and sell. You start out in this great one car greasy little garage that fits like old jeans, and after doing innumerable repair jobs you transition to this beautiful spotless three car garage whose floor you could lick. No warning no congratulations, just boom, you're there. I find the game terribly lacking in direction or helping anyone who doesn't know much about cars. You're on your own pal. No tips, suggestions, arrows, manuals you can check, nothing I found. I also wish it offered more advanced repairs like total engine repairs not just sub-assemblies. The game is a good start but needs a lot of improvement. More variety of cars and parts, American cars, hints and tips. It's a good time for $10 but mybe the future holds improvements. Thanks for reading.

reviewText: Well, being a real life mechanic I don't even know where to start with how frustrating this game is at times. But I'll just say I can tell whoever designed the vehicles has never touched a wrench, and decided against having someone who is a Mechanic or at least mechanicly inclined to assist in even naming parts, yet alone on how some parts come off the vehicle. I have to remove the rear differential to remove the drive shaft? Uh, no. And 90% of theparts you have to access from the wheel well can be accessed from under the vehicle, without even removing the wheels.\n\nAll in all, I actually would recommend this game amazingly, but that's because it's still a work in progress and has time to improve. Only advice is don't take mechanics lessons from it, you won't learn anything. And real mechanics beware, it'll drive you nuts.

reviewText:
This Game Is Great! 8.5/10!

A Simulator Where You Run Your Own Repair Shop! We've Been Waiting For Something Like That For A Long Time and Here It is.

This game is great for anyone who likes working on cars (Duh its in the name.)
The realism is a little off example you can run a car into the test track wall at 100+ Km/h and not get a penality for that action you did, You have to buy new rims each time you change a clients tires! Why couldn't you just buy the tire and then place it on the rim you already have? Like I said the realism is a little off.
But for the most part the game is really good, The sounds of the cars is pretty good and the with over 150 parts to repair/replace you will get the feeling of a Car Mechanic.
This game will need a decently good computer to run on good settings.
PS: This game as a sequal coming out around April or July 2015 so be on the look out for that.

reviewText:
VERY SUPRISED by how awesome this game is! Feels like a finished product for a change, not like other simulator games! Great sounds, great graphics, easy keyboard layout and generally fun to play, learning about different parts and problem finding.

Starts off telling you how to move around and using the action key to interact with your environment, then it lets you do your own thing; completing jobs, buying books to learn more (to level up), test driving the cars etc. Levelling up through the game gives you bigger garages and better tools!

Definitely worth the money and would recommend to anyone who loves cars and simulation games.

reviewText:
Where to start..
As someone who used to do this for a living, this game could have had it's uses. Unfortunately it does not reflect any of the work a mechanic actually does, i understand that it can't be too complex but there are mountains of things missing from the actual cars, (water pump but no radiator, hoses heater core etc etc) inlet manifold comes off like it's a toy while the exhaust manifold uses 4 bolts per exhaust port  and bolts to the block not the head, wheel bearings, brake pipes, you name it. Silly stuff like making you remove the entire exhaust system from the back to let you remove the exhaust manifold. or the intake ducting and the air mass meter to be able to remove the airbox to change the filter i can only assume was done to make it drag out the career mode.

Get someone who actually knows about cars to design the parts and it could have been good
Every chassis is identical so it just turns into a grind.
some of the explanations for the faults are complete gibberish
Check the oil for some reason becomes change it
telling you to change individual brake pads or do the discs but not the pads, changing oil without the filter and only individual spark plugs etc etc.

This could get people thinking the real thing is a breeze and why you will find people doing a DIY port and polish job by tipping sand into the intake of their running engine...

one to avoid IMO

reviewText: I run an automotive repair and customization shop and am an A.S.E. certified tech and I love the concept of the game but the execution was terrible. It is obvios that they did not employ anyone in the staff that is a mechanic. There are a huge amount of things overlooked (like where are all your tools?, theres a red tool box that is smaller than anything that could hold any usable amount of tools) Or how you buy brake pads individually(4 per car) (irl they are sold as a set per axle), and why is it harder to find parts in the game then it is in real life? It is also more frustrating trying to navigate the view and be able to click the parts then it is to do it in real life. Also the OBD scanner should be better than a $100 scanner since it is just a simulation....\n\nFor the most I wanted to love it but just couldnt, 1 star all the way

reviewText:
DO NOT GET THIS GAME! I bought this thinking it would have some gameplay to it. It is the most shallow point and click adventure ever. Even if you are a car mechanic, do not get this! It will make you feel ♥♥♥♥ about your life. As soon as I started playing, it felt like I had wasted money, so I Alt+F4. I feel sick to the gut about how much money I wasted on a half finished, boring concept. Even if you have watched videos on this, and think it would be even the slightest bit fun, heed my warning.

My problem with this game is that it has 3 inches of gameplay. You get a car, you buy some parts, you take parts out, you put some in, then you assemble the vehichle. It's like a 3D jigsaw. What seperates this and a 3D jigsaw, though, is a 3D jigsaw does not guide your hand every step of the way! If the person giving you the car has not already told you what it is, then driving it once around a track or sitting in the car will tell you. I really hate this, as it removes any concept that this game once had. It drops from a puzzle with depth to a point and click. You get a lot of the same car in this game, and the cars aren't even real, so it's not like a lack of license.

The controls are clunky. The camera slides like it's on a demonic rail from hell sent to bite you in the f*cking ♥♥♥♥. The mouse lags, and the head-sway would make you believe that you downed 3 bottles of painkillers before each job (I certainly thought about doing so). I understand that you can turn headsway off, but if you do that you feel like you have had a neck brace put on. The music is so loud and abrasive to my ears. It's not licensed, and I know that you can turn the music off, but that's boring. This game has NO middle ground!

I haven't even started on the mechanics. You can only access certain parts from certain angles. That part makes sense. My problem is that some parts make no sense as to where you extract them. You should take the gearbox out from the bottom, but no! You take it out through the top. Through the engine! Don't get me started on the nuts! You should unscrew nuts diagonally, but this doesn't matter, acoridng to Car Mechanic Simulator 2014. For a game specializing in CAR MECHANICS they don't know anything!

You can buy second hand parts from a dodgy website, but there is almost no point as you can either repair the parts, or buy them new. Second hand parts are never good enough. You could repair them, but that takes extra time, and it's a lot easier to just buy new ones.

To cleanse my ways, I am going to donate £13 worth of toys and stationary to the bravery box in a cancer ward. It's the only thing that my £13 could be spent on to justify spending so much on a game that made me feel sick. I do agree with funding indie developers, but only if they have good concepts. I was stupid to buy this in the first place. Learn from my mistake, or donate £13 to a teenage cancer trust. Your choice. http://www.clicsargent.org.uk/

reviewText: As a car enthusiast, I found the game to be overly simplified. The interface exaggerates the monotonous aspects of working on cars, while skipping entirely the actual difficulties and triumphs. The main workflow consists of getting a car with a job sheet. The sheet has a vague problem and a dollar amount you'll be paid if you fix the problem. The first assumption made here is that the person who wrote the job sheet knew what the problem was but failed to tell you. They also figured out how much it would cost for you to fix the problem and are charging the car owner that amount. If you fix exactly the problem, you will be profitable. This is a very flawed model since it gives no penalty for diagnosis. You can tear the entire car apart, find the item that has the most amount of wear, if that item can be replaced or repaired for the amount on the job sheet, then it's likely your problem. Rarely, the problem can be 2 or more parts that are marginal.\n\nThere are several makes" of car in this game
date: and several different configurations. Most cars and minivans are 4 cylinder
voteText: and a few performance cars are v6 (LOL) with rear wheel drive. All cars share most of the same parts. A front strut for the suv fits the economy car

votesHelpful: minivan
votesTotal: everything. There is no confusion about parts at all. The air filter fits everything

column32: or removing the part. Diagnosing the part makes it turn a color from green to red

column34: with 17% being the most common threshold for failed part. Remove the part
column35: go to the computer and buy another part

reviewText:
First impressions were fair to good.  Graphics are reasonable and frame rate is good on my rig.

The controls, particularly for the camera, are a little quirky.  Using WASD to manipulate the camera isn't ideal really in my opinion, the mouse is more appropriate for that function.

As you would expect from a budget title, the game lacks depth.  I found I was really quite bored after an hour.  Endless unbolting of parts, which, whilst realistic, becomes very tiresome.  The vast majority of jobs you receive are simplistic and in all honesty, even with my limited knowledge of car mechanics, there was no real puzzle here.  There is no businesss simulation" either.  A single click awards you with a one time bank loan.  That is about the only business decision you make.

You can purchase upgrades which improve the speed at which you remove bolts
date: or a percentage increase in income per jobs
recommended: but there are few options besides this.\n\nTest driving the cars is exactly the same each time and even on repairs you would expected to hear an indication of a fault
hoursPlayed: such as a work order describing knocking from the suspension
voteText:
I heard nothing.

I found the gameplay very repetitive indeed.  There is not much to recommend here I'm afraid.  It might keep a younger person occupied for a few hours but thats about it.  Educational value is minimal beyond explaining the names of car parts and their rough locations although even these are only accurate on a very basic level.

Cannot really recommend this title

reviewText: Mechanic Simulator is about as close to simulating a mechanic as Goat Simulator is at making you a goat.  You're forced to use WASD and mouse look instead of right-click and drag to move your view.  It's archaic and cumberome to use.  There are some very big issues with the interface and movement of this game let alone the gameplay.  One of the first jobs includes a fuel filter replacement but there's no indication where it is because there are no fuel lines or evap lines leading you to it.  You're left searching with a horrible 3D view panel for a little box where no fuel goes.  This game is nothing like working on a real car.  If you've ever worked on a car and know what you are doing then this game is definitely not for you.  It has great potential to be a mechanic simulator but it needs a ton more work especially on the way you look around and select things.  Is it worth $5?  Barely.  I'd think $3 would be a fair price for a game that feels like it should still be in alpha development.

reviewText:
The first game like this I ever played was Gear Head Garage put out by Snap-On.  The game was crude but had a huge mod group where people made real cars for the game to fix up and sell.

That game prompted me to purchase this game and I have to say as a real auto/truck tech the game is very much like real life.  Every symptom I have seen from the customer was correct to the causes.

How ever there is one thing that really bugs me.  The game requires removal of items to get to another item that you really dont have to do in real life.  Example is there was one job that required the replacement of the exhaust manifold.  To do this you have to remove the rear muffler, the rear exhaust pipe, the middle muffler, the middle exhaust pipe, the catalytic converter, and the forward exhaust pipe before you can remove the exhaust manifold.

When I have had to do this at work I have never removed the whole exhaust system, I have always broke the exhaust loose at the manifold to header pipe connection and then removed the manifold.

This is where this game in my opinion could be improved on is allowing the items to be removed without having to remove the whole system when it is not required.  Its like removal of the front strut you have to take the sway bar end link off first.  Well I dont remove them I remove the end that is attached to the strut and then remove the strut.  Like wise in the game the strut only has four bolts holding it to the spindle arm when in reality its two bolts with another three to six bolts holding it to the unibody at the top of the strut.

While these complaints are minor and do not effect the game itself I still recommend the game for those that want to experience real diaganostics and troubleshooting of vehicle problems.

reviewText:
Great visuals, good music and sound.  Easy controls make it quite accessable.
But after 3 hours of playing I've found it lacking in variety and the gameplay is too simple.

Despite the name, this is a car puzzle game, not a detailed simulator.

For me, someone who knows very little about cars, I got what a paid for - a learning game that has taught me more of the basics;  the names of various mechanical components and how they fit together, but I imagine anyone who already has that knowledge will lose intrest in this title very quickly.  Different vehicles in the base game all have the same components inside.

The main challenge of the game is a real world one - where is the part I need to pull out? and what else to I need to remove first to get it out?   Figuring this out is rewarding.  But there's no need to pick the right tool for the job, simply click a part to remove it or click repeatedly to unscrew it.

There's no time pressure either, no countdown clocks or waiting customers.  Having this as an option after the first few jobs might have spiced things up a bit.

Your camera can fly through the transparent body of the car to give you a better view of what you're removing, which is fine except when, despite the fact you can see a part, you can't remove it because you entered this view from the engine rather than the wheel.
This is a little frustrating because the game lacks feedback.  A simple audio cue of your 'character' saying Uh.  Can't reach that from here"  or "Whoops
date: no room under the car to pull that out."  might have prompted me to open the hood or raise the car on the lift rather looking around fruitlessly for a  prerequiste part to remove first.  Parts that are visible but inaccessable should have better visual cues
recommended: "greying out" when you mouse over them

votesTotal: but if you tinker with real engines
votesFunny: this won't fire you up.\n\nStill recommended for the quality of the production but I'd love to see a "pro" mode that increases the complexity of the engines and other components."

reviewText:
A very nice game for a simulator!

About the game: basically you get a clients car and you have to fix the problem. You have to check if car parts are ok (check tire condition, oil etc), repair parts or replace them if needed. There is either info about a part you need to replace/repair or you have to find the problem and solution yourself. You also do test drives (where acceleration, suspension, gears and breaks are tested) and tune the cars for that extra horsepower etc.

The most important thing is that you learn about cars and it's parts by playing this, so the game is also quite educational. Who knows.. might come in handy one day when you are on the road and your car happens to have a problem you might possibly easily fix right on the spot.

reviewText: Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 starts off in a garage as you take on the role of the Mechanic. The goal is simple: perform the tasks on the work order using your trusty wrench and diagnostic tools (including test drives), not to mention your two eyes to find and repair the various parts and make a profit.\n\nThe game itself isn't terrible, the graphics are quite good and the gameplay is fluid enough, but the repetition and free-roaming aspect of the game can become tedius if not completely irritating at times. To give an example of this, take a work order that simply says The car pulls to the right sometimes." You'll find yourself pulling the car apart to find the problem
date: then you need to walk to the computer to buy the new part

reviewText:
I recommend this game with a caveat. Specifically, the caveat is the price I paid: $6.79

It's definitely not worth $20. While it's fun, especially for someone like me who is pretty ignorant of cars and their inner workings, the game gets rather redundant after a while. I can see an experienced car guy be rather irked by this game after a few missions.

One of the dumbest aspects of the game is the used parts store. It's completely pointless, as the replacement parts you buy will not let you advance forward in the game.

So all in all, get this game if it's under $10 and you're a complete car newbie like myself. It's fun to learn some stuff about cars, but at the same time, gameplay and some gameplay mechanics are incredibly weak.

reviewText: For a game that calls itself a simulator
date:
there are several aspects of this game that fall far too short of the real-life experience of working on cars.

The first mistake I noticed is the missing human element. In this game, you will find no blank stares or slow mumbles. There are no memorable answers to simple questions, such as people claiming to own a Honda Elantra. The customers usually know what's wrong with their cars and leave understandable notes on the work order, which allows you to quickly find and correct the current problem. I cannot begin to explain how far from reality this actually is.

The another jab to the title of simulator" comes from the ease of installation or removal of parts. As any grease monkey will testify
recommended: parts just don't come off that easily. I was also sad to find that there was no way to curse at the vehicle for being difficult. The mechanic you play as must be a ghost
voteText: located next to the transmission
helpfulPercent: are installed and removed through the engine bay.\n\nLastly
votesHelpful: the cars are all clean. There is no grime to wash off
votesTotal: there are no fingernails lined with black grease. You will not find bandages on your arms and fingers because there are no impact or puncture wounds to heal. No mud
votesFunny: no oil
commentsCount: no antifreeze

reviewText: Does not correctly support multi-monitor setups.  The mouse cursor frequently goes outside the game window onto the second monitor - clicking then causes the game to minimize and return to Windows, which loses the immersion. There needs to be some options to control what plays on the radio and songs should cycle rather than play the same thing over and over again until it is manually changed.

reviewText:
100% Recommended at the $7 sale price. $20 for the regular price and I still think it's worth it. I'm 61/75 on the normal orders and still have 20 left on the offroad add-on.

Gameplay is smooth on ultra settings, except I have OA and DOF disabled because of my old GeForce 9600 GSO and running 1600x900 native resolution.

Game still looks very good with those settings.

The camera can be bothersome at times, but you can click on any part near the part you actually need to focus the camera quickly.

The only downfall is the repetative gameplay itself but it's still engaging and pushes you on to complete the order, and the next, and the next.

Personally I wish there was more depth, like being able to actually delve into the engine, or replace U-Joints and smaller stuff. But I understand this game is meant for everyone and people that don't know a lot about cars could get lost.

I would just like to see difficulty settings. Normal and Hardcore where Hardcore is much more mechanically inclined.

All in all, I recommend this title.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
So this game is sort of a neat premise with not enough effort put into its execution. It is, as many have already pointed out, somewhat limited in scope. You click to unscrew bolts, you inspect the condition of the parts, you order new ones from the computer and you replace the old ones. Done. Occasionally you test-drive the cars on this one small ugly test course.

So far, the insides of most cars I have repaied looked the same! If you get to work on a muscle car then the setup does change, but basically the insides only differ per type of car and not per car. All the major parts of a car are there but don't expect to be replacing some small stressed screw somehwere or repairing a crack in the windshield. This game does not go that deep.

But since I know almost nothing about cars, it did teach me a thing or two about them so mission accomplished I guess.

I recommend it but only if it's on sale. 20 euros is a bit too steep. The only thing this game really has going for it is its uniqueness, which is a shame because I think an in-dept car mechanic simulator would be an interesting game.

reviewText: though I recommend this game for general fun, it is not a true auto mechanic simulator nor should it be considered a learning tool for becoming one.  Their is no engine block disasembly or removal of pistons, crackshafts ect nor can you adjust the throttle.  The engines in all the cars are exactly the same, and if you work on a rear wheel drive car, the engine is mounted like a front wheel drive which is NOT how engines in RWD are monuted. The drive shaft comes out of seemingly nowhere and even if it's rear wheel drive the gear box has shoulders for a FWD.  The only engine configuration is the fuel injected I-4 and V 6 no uniquness or difficulty based on unfamiliarity, in fact, anyone can work on these cars, very basic stuff.  I took automotive service technology in vo-tech and know something about cars, this is totally inacurate.  However, I think there is a lot of BASIC stuff that can be learned from this game, as there is a lot of detail and work on suspension, though that is where it ends. reviewText:
What should I say about this game? Is it fun. Initially it is quite fun as you are presented with challenges. There were some problems I encountered with this game though. Some of the required parts to be changed are not clear. After you have solved all the campaign missions, things go downhill and the game just becomes routine and a bit boring.

I just wish there were more to do in the post game experience. It is almost hinted that you can do more with the engine, but you can't really. I wish there are more parts to replace or at least a more advanced mode or set of tools. In a way it is boring since it breaks down to running the car on the diagnostic path and the test track and then replacing all the parts as you need them. Or you have to replace something on the car first to get it running and test it. However, there is no challenge to this.

I did encounter a few things that I consider to be bugs. Some parts will not show their condition, unless you physically unscrew them. I sort of understand the logic to this, as you need to visually inspect some parts to know their condition, but it seems strange. Mostly I just wish there was more variety on the diagnostic techniques. Maybe more mini-games such as tyre balancing or having to set the torque on a wrench, add a cherry picker so we can do more with the engine, force the user to lift up the car to drop the transmission. Fix the radiator, fill it with coolant. Replace the sterring wheel, align the chassis.

Some problems that I have with the game is that there are no time constraints. You are free to take your time without worrying. You are also only given one car at a time to work on. It seems really strange that they give you this super deluxe car shop with the impression that you are making lots of money, but I have never seen any car workshop that only worked on one car at once. Other things I have a problem with is with the in-game parts catalog. There is no way to filter items by name or by condition. There is no quick sell option. What would be really great would be a parts checklist or log. Inspected x - condition y
date: took off part x - condition. Other issues
recommended: I think there should be a keys bound to enable switching between attach/detach
voteText: show/hide body or parts condition.\n\nI still recommend this game as an interesting distraction. Would I recommend the full price? It isn't really that much

reviewText:
I cant recommend this game, it have potential, but i think the devlopers doesnt havent very big plans on this title.
I know there will two expensions in the furture, but i guess this should be it. What things are negative:

- Dont like the radio, its quiet annoying. My girlfriend sings better then that.
- You cant instantly turn the radio off so go for silents gameplay.
- An other good future could be that you can listen to your own music selected by the radio.
- Some camera views are terrible, like filling the engine oil and need to go back to the oil stick to check the oil. Also removing oil is just terrible for camera angle..

- Other bad thing about the oil change, the oil collector unit is hard to position under the car, so the oil is always falling on the floor.
- There isnt really an tutorial ingame so you can learn where the parts are on the car, (i never saw a mechanic without brains or doesnt know where to start.
- You cant really disamble the whole engine, this is really an missed change to be a good game.
- Maybe some complain about my bad things i listed here and saying its a cheap maded game, then make it more expensive. Ill better like a good game i want to pay for, then buying a not so good game that would chase my whole live staying on my steam account..
- It looks like that the parts are all the same, i like to see more parts that arent interchangable with some brands of cars. This was already existing on the dos game `street rod`, and street rod 2`. How hard could it be to make a really good game and make good money on it, instead doing something an hope it would sell..
- What i also think is worse, the secondhand parts are always `junk` as you want to buy it(not usable anymore). I thought to would be more clever to buy a second hand part, but is was really worn out and so not usable anymore.
- I also like to see more and better music in this game..

As i said this game have potential, but i really like to see that the devlopers work this game better out! But then i could recommend it, otherwise not!!!

reviewText:
Well. What can I say??

I've been wanting to play this for a little while, and I've now managed to have a little blat..

First impressions? Well, as a mechanic by trade, I really wish it were that easy to remove bolts... But that's not the name of the game here is it? Granted the tutorial is 30 seconds long, but that, to me, sort of adds appeal, as it means you have to think about what you're doing. This isn't a mindless shoot em up. You have to think logically, especially when it starts getting into replacing a clutch and so on.

What needs to come off first before I can get to the real issue. Pretty much like a normal car.

As a really nice touch, I like the fact you get money returned for recycling!!

Granted, there's not much variation in the vehicles, like RWD, 4x4 etc, which would add more dimention to the game, but as it is, is has what a good majority of cars now are. Front Wheel Drive.

I'd like to see more parts to be added, and get down to the real nitty gritty parts, like circlips and split pins, you know, all the little fiddly bits, or even having a seized stud which you've got to use oxy-acetylene to warm up to get out, even a snapped bolt..

Maybe I'm being too traditional there, but these things happen!!

One thing that IS missing.. Girly calenders. Sorry for being sexist here ladies. I have yet to come across a garage that doesn't have a girly calender somewhere. And who in the world had an FSO Polonez poster on the wall?? hehehe! (1st garage, behind the lift control) Yes, I know RedDot are a Polish company before you start!

Ah! another good point.. A PROPER lift would be advantagous here. One where you specify the height or at least have complete free wheeling, instead of using a scissor jack??  Do garages really have lifts like these now? Be nice if the lifts were the double poster type, just so you could work at the height you want, not either on the floor or in the air.

Again, being picky because of grease monkey.. =)

Overall, if you want to learn a little about cars and like a little challenge, then this game is ideal.
To me, this is a fun game, not a sim, but I enjoy it enough to keep playing.

Usually how i'd try and feel out an unfamiliar car is i'd tract the fluid lines. In this one, you have no real way of knowing the fuel filter is in the rear, Also the camera is pretty bad. reviewText: As a car enthusiast, I found the game to be overly simplified. The interface exaggerates the monotonous aspects of working on cars, while skipping entirely the actual difficulties and triumphs. The main workflow consists of getting a car with a job sheet. The sheet has a vague problem and a dollar amount you'll be paid if you fix the problem. The first assumption made here is that the person who wrote the job sheet knew what the problem was but failed to tell you. They also figured out how much it would cost for you to fix the problem and are charging the car owner that amount. If you fix exactly the problem, you will be profitable. This is a very flawed model since it gives no penalty for diagnosis. You can tear the entire car apart, find the item that has the most amount of wear, if that item can be replaced or repaired for the amount on the job sheet, then it's likely your problem. Rarely, the problem can be 2 or more parts that are marginal.\n\nThere are several makes" of car in this game
date: and several different configurations. Most cars and minivans are 4 cylinder
voteText: and a few performance cars are v6 (LOL) with rear wheel drive. All cars share most of the same parts. A front strut for the suv fits the economy car
helpfulPercent: performance car
votesHelpful: minivan
votesTotal: everything. There is no confusion about parts at all. The air filter fits everything
votesFunny: as does exhaust pipes
commentsCount: mufflers
column16: cats
column19: end links
column20: shocks
column21: struts
column22: fuel pump
column26: and about a dozen other parts.\n\nThe mechanics of the game are tedious. You get your car and job sheet. You have to figure out which part to replace
column27: but some of the parts you cannot diagnose till you've taken other parts off. For example
column28: if you want to diagnose any suspension component
column29: you have to remove the wheel before you can diagnose anything else. Once the wheel is removed
column30: you can diagnose a layer of components. Diagnosis consists of either selecting diagnose mode
column32: or removing the part. Diagnosing the part makes it turn a color from green to red
column33: with green being the 100% effective and red being 1% effective. It appears that anything below 30% is your bad part
column34: with 17% being the most common threshold for failed part. Remove the part
column35: go to the computer and buy another part
column36: sell the bad part on the used part market
column37: and then install the new part. Put everything back together again. Get paid
column39: repeat till you're sick of it
column40: which for me was about 2 weeks. One area in particular that bugs me is the brake caliper removal sequence. I have removed brake calipers many times
column42: trucks and motorcycles. in every case
column43: the brake pads stayed in the caliper when I removed the caliper. The game has the brake pads stuck to the rotors
column44: so an additional step is needed to remove the pads.\n\nThe problems encountered are textbook
column45: and the solutions are also textbook. Anyone who knows about fixing cars will know immediately what the problem is when reading the job sheet. Could this 'game' be used to gain experience in fixing cars... maybe. One would understand more fully what each component was and how it fits into the whole
column46: and how it's failure would impact the whole. The part about the actual work
column47: I believe would only help someone by giving them a general idea of where on a car that item lives. The work portion is so over simplified as to be a great source of laughs for the first 100 times
column48: then tedious boredom after that. There is no searching for the correct sized socket
column49: then discovering you need the deep wall
column50: and don't have one in that size
column53: so now you have to use a pipe wrench and buy a new bolt... or discovering you cannot fit your hand into the space provided so you make an elaborate contraption of extensions and universal joints only to discover you didn't need to take that bolt out after all. There's nothing about anti-seize
column58: nothing at all about tools. I never had to dig out the welder
column62: gloves or safety glasses during the game
column63: which makes it totally unrealistic. None of the bolts are ever stuck
column65: or broken. They're always easy to remove
column66: and install. I never burned my hand on a hot exhaust
column67: or got shocked by a faulty spark plug wire
column68: or got battery acid on my good jeans
column69: or spilled oil all over the engine and had a smoke bomb when the car was started. Also
column70: you cannot install parts out of sequence
column71: so the all too common scenario of discovering you forgot to install the wheel bearing seal after you finished putting everything back together never happens.\n\nI cannot really imagine an audience for this game. Maybe servicemen overseas who miss working on their cars
column72: or prison inmates... A teenager should have their own jalopy to work on and learn from. An adult inclined toward this will have a project car to work on

reviewText:
This simulator sits on an odd waypoint; likely too difficult for those who know nothing about cars, but too easy for those who do. As a result the game quickly becomes a tedious follow through of removing bolts in to replace certain parts. The only real difficulty lies in establishing what the customer actually wants done sometimes.

If you're looking for an updated version of Gearheads Garage, this aint it, thats for sure. The game could have done with perhaps trying to be more educational if they were targeting the non-mechanically minded. For example, instead of having someone remove a trailing rod, it'd have been clever to have a brief description available as to what this part does, symptoms of when its gone wrong and so on.

As it stands, the cars all look the same, you're limited to just how much actual work you can do on a car and it lacks the realism of your typical garage in that you can't half-♥♥♥ a job then overcharge the customer.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: If you're looking for the new Gearhead Garage, this is not it. Although fairly detailed graphics wise, it falls flat compared to what  we all know this is suppose to replace. The test driving albeit a neat feature is terrible. An arcade racing game has better handling mechanics than this. But test driving aside the core mechanics of, well, being  amechanic, just doesn't feel the same as it did in Gearhead Garage. Not to mention the lack of an auction/build your own projects (Which IMO was what brought Gearhead Garage to life) is missing, so it's just you fixing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cars and you really have no motivation since you're essentially doing the same thing over and over without a goal to get to, like saving up to fix a beater you bought at an auction. One last point I think is pretty important is the inability to actually take the entire car apart. The game dumbs it down to only a handful of parts that can be removed and replaced while others are just static imagery, as if they didn't exist. All in all, the game does not live up to the expectations of a 15 year old game. It really should have.

reviewText:
Absurdely captivating- would buy again

While this is clearly a low budget game and I could play Diablo 3 instead this simulator has its charms. I can't really explain why I'm in mission 64 right now except maybe the fun hunting for an error and fixing it. Maybe I'll should spent some time as a mechanic one day.

It plays like some kind of meditation but may feel like a chore to some players so you should definitely try out the demo first. Also I hope to see more parts and variation in the soundtrack, car models, upgrades, test drives, more economics etc. in CMS 2015.

The good stuff- fixing cars, music and a rare polish feel to the game. Missions are loosely based on some real mechanics I guess - people driving offroad with their city suvs, illegal racers tuning their chips - lol - next please make a system administrator simulator next with the same vague problem descriptions from users to figure out...

Controls are a bit difficult since you have to focus on a part first then click again to remove it, game has no serious technical difficulties though, no crashes and can be alt-tabed also so solid work from the coders here.

It's a great game, definitely worth picking up when it's on sale.

I would say that it is semi-educational and if you don't know anything about cars, you'll definitely learn a thing or two by playing this game. I think the developers could have made it more detailed with the car parts, examining and assembling/unassembling of the cars.

There isn't many car models in the game either, you end up doing a lot of repairs on about 4 different cars, it would have been nice to have worked on a variety of cars.

I found the test driving to be useless, it doesn't tell you anything about what's wrong with the car, the horrible sounds are not existent, the bumps, the steering wheel pulling to one side, none of it. You can be a dodgy mechanic in the game by keeping the damaged parts from your previous repair jobs and then taking the good parts off the cars from the new jobs and replacing them with the damaged parts then all you have to do is go to your inventory and sell the good parts.

It does start to get challenging as some jobs require you to read the customers complaint and go over the car and find the problem and then rectify it which made it more interesting to play as time went on.

Somethings are completely off in this game like the pricing of car parts, since when does a spark plug cost 35$ or a battery costing 350$. Some jobs pay ridiculous amounts as well, which isn't realistic in terms of real life and since when does a mechanic repair a fuel or water pump. It is quite a repetitive game, the developers did include two add-ons which made it a bit more exciting to play but there has been so much left out of this game. also there could have been so much that could have been added to this game.

reviewText:
At first at gives you a brief tutorial on how to move and change the breaks, but then it leaves you on your own to explore the mechanics of the game (pun very much intended). The costumers sometimes give you very specific problems which makes it very easy to work with, but sometimes they just give you a symptom and you have to figure out what causes it using your own instincts and the experience that you have gathered so far. I really enjoyed that aspect of the game, and it allows me to test my already lousy knowledge in cars to the limit, and it might serve me well when my car starts to give in.

The mouse movement was a bit weird at first, but you get used to it. The music library is mainly dubstep music, and I wish they added a proper radio like in euro truck simulator 2. Also, there is no quick way to get to the inventory  or to switch between assemble and disassemble without pressing the right mouse key to bring the menu up, or I somehow missed it.

But overall, this game is very entertaining, and according to many people it comes very close to show how real cars work.

reviewText:
A great game/simulator for anyone with any interests in cars. The game's tutorial does a goodjob at explaining the simple controls and how the game works. You DO NOT need to be an experienced mechanic" like some reviews say to be able to play the game. HOWEVER you do need to know at least the general layout of a car. The game does help you with identifying parts. Just mouse over a part and it will give you the name or show you any other parts that need to be disassembled first.

You start off with small kind of gritty garage and eventually work your way up to more advanced garages that have more features to them. The orders are always random and seems to be endless leaving LOTS of replayability. There's even a mode where it just keeps going on and on and on and never ends (has to be unlocked by playing career mode first however). The graphics are great and you can see how bad a part is damaged just by looking at it. The test driving is a little weird but it's more of a minigame to qucikly identify the condition of parts and where the problem with the car may be.

Overall this game is great if you know a little bit about cars but you want to learn more this will really help you out and you'll be surprised at how easy and quick you learn the different parts of the vehicle and what they do."

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This is a fun game if you go into it with the right attitude. (Mainly that you're buying a $15 dollar game and not a $60 dollar one). There is some variations on the cars you work on (eventually there are V-6's and some 4x4's, no V-8's). The game definitely expects that you have some general knowledge of cars when troubleshooting problems. If you know nothing about what places to look when you encounter a problem you might be a little lost. There is definitely no hand holding. The game suffers from a few minor annoyances with camera angles, lack of button shortcuts, and sometimes having to back out of a view to get to access to a part you are staring at, but they are very minor and not game breaking. This is definitely a lite" sim. The problem solving is probably the most enjoyable part
date: just getting something to work on
recommended: figuring it out as quickly as possible and then challenging yourself to fix it as quickly as possible. It might have been nice if they put a timer on you
hoursPlayed: or only allowed you to comlete so many jobs per day. There are upgrades for people that actually bothered to look. You can upgrade your wrench speed
voteText: part/problem identification
helpfulPercent: how much you pay for parts and how much you get paid on a job. Once those are maxed out
votesHelpful: money becomes meaningless. Also when you upgrade to better garages
votesTotal: new types jobs become available. I went in with no expectations and was pleasantly surprised. Will probably put 20 hours into this which more than I have put into some AAA first person shooters. Couple of sidenotes: the in game music is decent and I haven't gotten sick of it (you could probably customize it if you wanted too). Also some of the dialogue is hilarious
votesFunny: the devs tried to stick a little humor in the problem descriptions between the translation and what they were actually trying to say
commentsCount: I definitely had a few laughs."

reviewText:
I am still uncertain about this game. The whole idea and the high level of detail is highly appealing. However I am struggling with the controls. There's room for improvements:

* Camera rotation in assembly mode is just odd with keys: very clumsy and unintuitive. The mouse would be a much better idea
* Ordering parts is hell on earth: So many items without a quick search or filters. Buying many things will end in a click orgy for confirmation. Why not use a checkout mechanic?
* Options not available in game mode
* Quick menu is a nice idea, but it should make available especially buying stuff.
* Where are the parts I have to examine/repair/replace? I like to learn something about cars and I don't know for example where the oil filter is. This may be fun for trial and error, but can leave you at a loss in some situations. Some guidance if needed should be implemented. Could be manuals and with upgrades, even augmented reality.
* Head/Camera swaying while moving around. Please make this an option, I feel seasick. When I look at things in real life at least my head is not moving around unvoluntarily.
* Mouse wheel not working in game browser to buy stuff
* Funds are covered by browser window

reviewText:
Nice game to improve everyones knowledge about which mechanical parts a car basically consists of and how they are basically attached.
The game didn't crash once, so far and I didn't find any bug.
The graphics are ok ... not great but absolutely acceptable.
The music is fine but repetative after a while.

On the downside the tuning part is a bit weird and only includes chiptuning". At least as far as I have played.
And unfortunately you can't disassemble the engine.
The driving part is not what this game is about
date: and you can feel and see that. There is no difference in the driving physics if something is damaged or not and you can't really see anything in the mirrors for example. Driving the car is good for only one thing. After your "testdrive" you can see the condition of many parts
recommended: so you don't have to inspect them each.\nAnother thing that bored me after a while was the fact
hoursPlayed: that every part in every car is at the same location. They look all the same underneath. The only small differences can be found between a V6 and a Straight4 engined car in combination with rear
voteText: front or 4x4. Every V6 is exactly the same
helpfulPercent:
every S4 is exagtly the same etc.

In my opinion there is potential which so far sadly hasn't been realized. But maybe some of those things will be added since there are already 2 addons announced.

In the end I had fun for a few hours finding the errors just using the rough descriptions of the virtual car owners.
"Car Mechanic Simulator 2014" is definitely worth its price (it wouldn't be
votesHelpful: if the price was higher) if you are interested in car mechanics. I don't regret to have bought it."

I've learned a lot from this game. reviewText:
I played a version of this game many many many  years (over a decade ) ago. It's pretty much the same except now there are work orders,a test drive section, a parts ordering mechanism,and a radio. Overall it's the same game. (but it was on sale for less than 3 bucks so what the hell I picked it up).

Let me say this, as a simulator this game falls wayyyy short, I've never done a brake job that didn;t have caliper bracket bolts or a bracket for that matter so yeah not too realilistic there. The prices are very odd, there's no pressing out bearings (so far anyway) and one of the first 5 jobs i was supposed to test an alternator...well when I removed the thing it said 6% cheapest option was replacement, ordered part put it on, got the belt on, took the battery out (1%) cheapest option was repair (90 some dollars....what shop doesn't have a charger to  repair" a battery for free?) put it all together went to close out the repair and low and behold it said to test alternator...what the ♥♥♥♥ does it matter now that i replaced it? and it wouldn't let me just check the condition of the old alternator... so ♥♥♥♥ that.
Other things to note; the mouse is laggy in game
