reviewText:
It's a very nice idea and mostly well made.
But a few horrible things make the game unplayable for me. Graphics and sound are good enough, but the interface is very lacking.

Main problem: the way way camera/mouse behaves. It's hard to describe, but you have to move the mouse VERY carefully or you end up swaggering - every time you move the mouse, the camera moves too.

Another problem is the game doesn't really help you - I'm no mechanic. I have no idea where the fuel filter might be (somewhere near the gas tank, I'd assume?).
Unfortunately, the game doesn't even indicate where the item in question might be, unless you're already very close. (Case in point, until you think of lifting the car, you don't even know there's another place to tinker UNDER the car. All other options are constantly shown (hood, wheels, side door), but not the one below the car, even if it's directly part of your current job?

A minor nuisance: to change game settings you have to leave the current game mode and get to the main screen again.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This was the first game I played that revolved around cars, and it's what inspired me to go take the air filter out of my car and learn more about mechanics! I only paid like two dollars for it just to give it a try. Who knew it'd make me love cars?

It's a one-of-a-kind game, there is nothing quite like this one out there. While this game may seem a bit limited in concept or design, the sequel is definitely not. CMS 2015 is one of the biggest improvements in game quality that I've ever seen from a small game developer. I give this game a 9/10 for being remarkably original and replayable, and the sequel a solid 10/10.

If you like this game, or want to know how cars work, buy the sequel. It's worth every cent!

reviewText:
I found it difficult to recommend this game and equally difficult not to. I finally settled on recommending it because it seems to succeed at what it sat out to do. It is a competent simulator. You should plan on reading the steam forums a lot if you are not mechanically inclined or not familiar with what makes an automobile work. That being said, you also don't have to be an ASE Certified master technician to enjoy the game.

You have an economy system with progression in the form of better equipment and money boosts. You do have to purchase the parts you intend to use so there is a failure state if you are not careful (you can reset scenarios though). During career you will advance from a small repair shop to a state of the art complex. Parts that you can interact with are highlighted and show colored “health” represented by a percentage meter. Some parts have to be removed to be examined. The parts that can be removed are usually highlighted and if you are required to remove a certain part to get to another they are shown in red to make things easier. An example would be removing tires to work on the brakes. There are also different views you can choose from removing the body rotating the camera and showing “health” of the parts. Graphical fidelity is competent but could have been better. Since this isn't a AAA title though I can accept it.

It is not without its problems though. I do have experience and education behind me for automotive service and repair so I didn't really get hung up on any of the scenarios that I played. I can easily see where this game may be too advanced for beginners wanting to learn about cars and it is a shame that there is no hint system to speak of (or at least that I was able to find). My biggest complaint with the game is the navigation. I had to exit the “wheel” section, for example to access the “engine” area (like the transmission bell housing) which was clearly in view already. It made it unnecessarily convoluted and drawn out even though I knew exactly what I had to do.

I would have liked to have seen more choice in tools and a way to torque bolts to the proper specs as well as some tire changing/balancing stations but that may just be because I’m really into this kind of work in real life. I would recommend this to anyone with a strong interest in the game but if your interest is only passing you may want to wait for a sale.

reviewText:
If you can live with having to take the front wheels off endless amount of times and have a basic knowledge of car mechanics, this game is pretty enjoyable. A shame there's no real option to alter the soundtrack beyond dubstep, quiet dubstep and off but I can live with that. The camera is pretty ♥♥♥♥-ish, but the sound effects are spot on and add to the atmosphere of being in a garage.

If you don't have much in the way of car knowledge, you might struggle for a while to diagnose the various issues on the car; but that's nothing that can't be sorted with a test drive, trial and error when stripping the car down and as a last resort, Google. Don't let not knowing the difference between a sump plug and a rubber bushing stop you from getting into what is a very pretty game with a solid idea behind it.
I'd say the asking price is about right, don't expect this game to last you forever and don't expect too much of it. But for what it is, you get a decent amount of game :)

reviewText:
Absurdely captivating- would buy again

While this is clearly a low budget game and I could play Diablo 3 instead this simulator has its charms. I can't really explain why I'm in mission 64 right now except maybe the fun hunting for an error and fixing it. Maybe I'll should spent some time as a mechanic one day.

It plays like some kind of meditation but may feel like a chore to some players so you should definitely try out the demo first. Also I hope to see more parts and variation in the soundtrack, car models, upgrades, test drives, more economics etc. in CMS 2015.

The good stuff- fixing cars, music and a rare polish feel to the game. Missions are loosely based on some real mechanics I guess - people driving offroad with their city suvs, illegal racers tuning their chips - lol - next please make a system administrator simulator next with the same vague problem descriptions from users to figure out...

Controls are a bit difficult since you have to focus on a part first then click again to remove it, game has no serious technical difficulties though, no crashes and can be alt-tabed also so solid work from the coders here.

reviewText:
This simulator sits on an odd waypoint; likely too difficult for those who know nothing about cars, but too easy for those who do. As a result the game quickly becomes a tedious follow through of removing bolts in to replace certain parts. The only real difficulty lies in establishing what the customer actually wants done sometimes.

If you're looking for an updated version of Gearheads Garage, this aint it, thats for sure. The game could have done with perhaps trying to be more educational if they were targeting the non-mechanically minded. For example, instead of having someone remove a trailing rod, it'd have been clever to have a brief description available as to what this part does, symptoms of when its gone wrong and so on.

As it stands, the cars all look the same, you're limited to just how much actual work you can do on a car and it lacks the realism of your typical garage in that you can't half-♥♥♥ a job then overcharge the customer.

reviewText:
If you have ever played Gearhead Garage and enjoyed it, then you're going to compare Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 to it. And while that is not necessarily a bad thing, it does mean you're likely to be hoping that this game builds on that experience. On the other hand, if you've never played Gearhead, you're probably be new to this concept of game, as nothing like it really exists. So, are you going to be disappointed?

Firstly, you're likely going to have some interest in cars, if not, I'm not sure this will appeal to you. In order to get by in this game, you will need a basic understanding of car components.

The game starts of well, introducing you to the controls. The first task directs you to operating the radio, the various car tools, car lift, etc. All too quickly though, you're on your own. Each task arrives in the form of a work sheet with a list of jobs to do, and a description of the customer's problem. The list can give you an obvious task, such as replace the oil, or it can be completely useless,  such as directing you to replace all the broken parts. In the latter the customer description may give you a clue, but sometimes that can be ambiguous, such as explaining they went off-road, yet not describing if that meant they were trying some 4x4r stuff, or they happened to have some sort of accident, or they may just tell you that it won't start. A side note on the radio, the music drove me to distraction, I'm sure some people will like it. I turned the radio off, only to find it doesn't turn off, but switches channels for something equally awful. I ended up going to the main game menu options and turning the music off.

There are a number of diagnostic methods you can undertake. On the first level, you can use the ODB to check the engine and electrics, and you can take the car for a test drive. Level two upwards gives you access to a rolling road, to test brakes and suspension. After you have performed the diagnostics it will colour code the parts tested. You also have the ability to physically examine individual parts in turn, but this can be time consuming if you don't know which part might be at fault. Some part also need removing to be examined, which is even more frustrating if it is okay.

The test drive sounds like fun? Well, no. It's a very basic car driving experience, either viewed from the driver's seat or a rear third person view. The objective, of which there is no guidance, is to follow a set out course, which first tests acceleration, then braking, followed by a slalom (steering test), finally ending with an uneven road (suspension test). Follow the glowing gates and you can't go wrong. The feedback delivered through the driving simulation is poor. You have no way of judging if acceleration or braking is adequate, even more so when there are a number of different car models to try. The same goes for the suspension test. Steering problems sometimes show up on the slalom when you experience severe under-steer, but to be honest the simulation is so poor, the steering can be bad even when it doesn't need repairing.

Back in the workshop, where you will spend most of your time, you can switch the view from a normal view, or to having the parts colour coded from green to red, green representing 100% quality and red, 0% quality. Sounds straight forward. Unfortunately there is no guidance as to what is acceptable quality, will 50% cut it? Or does it have to be 75% and greater? It can end up being trial and error. In the end, it is just quicker to buy new and replace anything you're not sure about.

There are seven main areas to investigate, the four wheels, under the bonnet, underneath the front and underneath the rear. So, you've identified what needs fixing. Now you need to remove the broken part. This is just a matter of click on the part to focus on it, then clicking again to either remove the part, or show the bolts that need to be undone first. Undoing bolts is a matter of clicking on them and holding the mouse button until the bolt is removed. You can alter the view, rotate around, above and below. You can also zoom in and out.

So the part is removed, what now? Well, there may be the chance to repair it, or buy a new or used replacement. Repairing parts is very limited, there are so few parts that can be repaired. Buying used is almost always a waste of time, as the condition of the part is pot luck and can't examined before buying. Also as previously mentioned, this leaves you with the problem as to just what is acceptable quality? So, if you can't repair a part you're best of buying new. The parts to be bought are listed alphabetically, and this seemed odd to me, as I would have preferred similar parts to be next to each other. As an example, the exhaust comes in numerous sections, but because each part is named after its position such as rear muffler, or middle muffler, they a separated by all the other parts that fall between the letters M and R. If you have numerous parts to buy, such a full set of brake pads, you have to click eight times on the break pads, and confirm you want to buy each one. This becomes tedious, and could have easily been rectified with a simple basket and quantity system, like all online shops employ. There is no margin for error here, if you buy the wrong part, you can't cancel it. You could sell it back at a massive reduction, but you're just best off keeping the part in a hope you have a need for it later. You can also sell back the worn parts, but you don't make much on them, and the process is only worth doing to keep you inventory tidy, as the worn parts serve no purpose, you'll not get an opportunity to use them.

The range of cars isn't very varied, and consists of 4 cylinder or v6 petrol engines. The running gear, comprises of 2 wheel drive and 4 wheel drive. There are several exhaust systems. In general though, it's not long before you seen everything, and the repetition sets in.

There are three levels to work through, the second introduces the rolling road, the third introduces chip tuning. Chip tuning seems almost pointless. You certainly won't notice the improvements in the test drive, if you can be bothered to try our the improvement (there's no requirement to do so, nor incentive). To tune the car you need to align three power blocks, and then save the setting to the EEPROM, and test. The challenge here is moving the blocks to achieve the right level of tuning, from 5% to 45%. As you move one block, it affects the other two. There may be some logic to this, but really, it's not worth the time and effort to work out. It doesn't take long to find the desired level. Once you complete the third level at 76 jobs, you unlock the endless mode. However, I'm not sure the game has anything left by this point to make me want to play forever.

There are upgrades to be bought along the way which will do the following, reduce the time to undo bolts, automatically examine random parts, increase the money made per job, and reduce the cost of parts. There are ten levels for each item. The least useful if the auto examination of parts, as most part end up being covered by diagnostic tests.

The game could have been made more interesting by adding to the challenges, for example, setting a time limit to get the job done. There is no real incentive to read the job sheet, you could just examine every part and just replace the poor quality stuff and still turn a profit. The test drive, there is no penalty for crashing the car. The used parts are almost a waste of time, I think I was able to use them in about two levels. Replacing the oil, you're provided with a used oil drum, but it doesn't matter if you drain the sump all over the workshop floor, you don't see it, there is no consequence. There are no project" cars to be bought and worked on that you can sell for profit.

The graphics are fairly nice
date: and the tear down of the cars is of a fairly sufficient depth
recommended: only marred by the low number of variat"

reviewText:
This game is NOT like Gear Head Garage if anyone reamembers that game. But it is a lot of fun. But it does certainly has room for improvement. But I higlhly recommend playing the DEMO first before blindly purchasing it based on players reviews.

I sort went into this game thinking cool another Gear Head Garage game, but sadly it is not that in any shape or form. First off you are given jobs, and given a certain amount of how much the job cost. It is up to you to pin point the problem based on what the customer said or by test driving, or doing a test tech in bigger garages.

One thing I learned while playing is the vehicle will have a lot of red parts, but you won't have enough money to buy/fix them all, just buy/fix what the person wanted and send it on its way. Buying/Fixing the red parts will put your shop in a early grave, so while tempting. Just DON'T do it.

One job that really threw people off was the fuel filter job. While having replaced the fuel filter in my car recently. I knew it was in or near the gas tank, so I went there right away. But other's stumbled on this job for a long time.

Now I said this game has much needed improvements.

Like jobs, they need to be rewarding or graded on how well you did also if you missed something major.

They should of done a story line or something to make the game interesting, but there really isn't any voices. And if you shut music off it's really really really quiet. Other than the occasional sound of the nuts coming off

Also the ability to just build a vehicle from the ground up and they paint it cool and sell it. While this isn't technically what mechanic does, this game based on the jobs, isn't technically what a mechanic does either, I never been to a shop where the customer pays for the job first, unless it's routine maintenance.  With that being said it should have the option of adding parts in case there is a bigger problem than originially thought.

Also there needs to be more parts. Able to fix more parts. More second hand parts,, in much better condition. Since most of those parts are bit of a rip off.  Also the parts cost a lot. I mean A LOT. Oil Filter costing 50 bucks.

The camera angle is something to be desired. especially in the back of the vehicle. I had a hard time viewing the vehicle. Sometimes the WASD buttons would reverse.


How do you get to bigger badder garages, by doing jobs, that is how. I am not sure how long I played but didn't seem like very long and I got my 2nd garage pretty fast.

Changing oil is pretty routine. But changing oil in the 2nd garage is odd. You have put it in this catch oil pan and you have be very percise where it is or you lose 100 dollars. The first garage wasn't like that you just drained the oil and that was that. Just seems to be a step back, instead of a step forward. And in the 2nd garage for sure, why can't you now fix tires? One of the tires in the game cost either 1600 or 1700 for one tire, I could see if it was all 4 tires. But this is just one tire. Jobs don't pay a lot, so replcaining one tire is really expensive.

On the plus side of things there is going to be FREE DLC. So perhaps some improvements in game play as well more things to do. While I do reommend this game. I really recommend playing the DEMO first.

Here is hoping the Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is taking the ideas of the fans and making EVEN better than the original.

reviewText: I'm really enjoying this game for getting my head around the basics of how cars are put together. I'd really enjoy levels of detail that it just doesn't have yet and I hope future versions are able to continue getting even more realistic, actually tracking particular car models and better understanding of how the individual bits fit together, maybe even 'building' one from scratch.\n\nThe driving simulation leaves a lot to be desired, but it is far from the key point of the game. Also the navigation within the garage could take advantage of better right-click functionality for camera manipulation. Other than that quite a solid offering and the content more than makes up for it.

reviewText:
Definitely buy this game if you want to learn some basic mechanics like brake pads/disc or advanced mechanics, but i should warn you that the game is based on modern cars so if you have a 2006 Ford Focus it wouldent look the same such as the engine etc. Be cautious that this game will give you a rough idea about mechanics but will not help you with the squeking noise coming from your engine etc. Hope this review helped you.
I know my timed played is very little but you can cover so much of this game in a short time so i thought why not do a review.

Game recommendation: 7/10
Game overall: 8/10

reviewText: This is actually really cool.  A good idea that is well executed, with just enough detail to make a non-mechanic feel as though he's solving simplified real-world car issues, while avoiding making it un-approachable with cumbersome controls or means of interacting with the vehicles.\n\nA good game, I definitely recommend for anyone wanting, well, a Car Mechanic Simulator that's easy to approach.
